table.caption: City Encounters (Levels 2-4)
rows: A {@creature mapach tinkerer|HWCS} with a hand cart of goods distracts the party with his marvelous wares while his {@creature hedge bard|HWCS} partner attempts to pickpocket them.

An innocent {@creature cervan priest|HWCS} is accosted by {@dice 1d4} {@creature birdfolk guard|HWCS|birdfolk guards}. These birdfolk are criminals who've stolen Perch Guard uniforms, and the party will be rewarded for their capture.

A visiting {@creature vulpin noble|HWCS} is interested in seeing the sights. Show them around town by rolling again on this table. They will accompany the party for this encounter, and should they survive, will reward the party 20 gp for the invigorating time.

A gathering of acrobatic street performers. If high enough level, a party member with the Sharp Mind trait, or who makes a DC 14 Intelligence check, will recognize a {@creature gallus monk|HWCS} among them from a wanted poster.

A citywide parade to honor Gaspard, the Champion. There are jousts, fencing matches, and other contests in which the party can participate. Defeat a {@creature jerbeen swashbuckler|HWCS} in a duel to win a magic item.
A mysterious death. If players are high enough level, this could lead to a fight with the {@creature corvum assassin|HWCS} who was paid to perform the murder.
A bar fight breaks out between {@dice 1d4} {@creature mapach bandit|HWCS} patrons and {@dice 1d4} {@creature birdfolk militia|HWCS}.
A pair of {@creature jerbeen thief|HWCS|jerbeen thieves} steal from the party. This leads back to their {@creature vulpin captain|HWCS} leader, who runs a pickpocketing ring in town.
table.name: Appendix E: Random Encounters; City Encounters (Levels 2-4)

table.caption: Cave Encounters (Level 1)
rows: {@dice 1d2} {@creature gray ooze|mm|gray oozes} conceal themselves as stagnant pools.
{@dice 1d2} roosting {@creature swarm of emberbats|HWCS|swarms of emberbats} drop from the ceiling.
The party finds a 6-foot-tall bioluminescent mushroom.
Two {@creature sticky slime|HWCS|sticky slimes} and a {@creature caustic slime|HWCS} attack.
table.name: Appendix E: Random Encounters; Cave Encounters (Level 1)

table.caption: Coast Encounters (Level 4)
rows: The party finds a small shrine to Gesme within a hidden grotto. The first player to pray here gains the ability to cast {@spell clairvoyance} once, without material components.
2 {@creature raptor explorer|HWCS|raptor explorers} are leading a {@creature strig tracker|HWCS} bounty hunter to the party.
{@dice 1d4} giant petrels circle overhead (use the stat block for a {@creature giant eagle}, but with a 30 ft. swim speed).
A violent storm rolls in. If the party chooses not to take shelter, they must make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw while traveling, suffering a level of {@condition exhaustion} on a failure.
A mass of seaweed turns out to be a {@creature shambling mound}.
A ship is stolen from the docks by {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature birdfolk sailor|HWCS} pirates, led by a {@creature jerbeen swashbuckler|HWCS}.
A sinking ship is spotted with its crew aboard. There are {@dice 1d3} {@creature hunter shark|mm|hunter sharks} circling in the water.
A crashing wave sweeps in, and the party must make a DC 14 Strength saving throw or be swept 80 feet into the sea, where a {@creature water elemental} lies in wait.
table.name: Appendix E: Random Encounters; Coast Encounters (Level 4)

table.caption: Forest Encounters (Level 1-2)
rows: {@dice 2d4} {@creature mapach bandit|HWCS|mapach bandits} ambush the party.
{@dice 1d2} {@creature swarm of emberbats|HWCS|swarms of emberbats} attack the party.
{@dice 1d4} {@creature magmin} can be spotted burning foliage through the trees. They haven't started a fire yet, but they will if left unchecked.
The party finds a moss covered shrine to Reya. The first character that stops to pray here gains the ability to cast {@spell elevated sight|HWCS} once.

{@dice 1d4} {@creature mapach bandit|HWCS|mapach bandits} and a {@creature jerbeen thief|HWCS} spring from the forest, offering safe passage for a road toll of 3 gp per party member. They will attack if the toll is not paid immediately.
{@dice 1d3} {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} led by a {@creature dire wolf} attack the party.

A {@creature birdfolk skirmisher|HWCS} on patrol is struggling in a large spider web and calling for help. He has been bound in silk, requiring a DC 15 Strength check or one round using a cutting tool to free him. There are {@dice 1d2 + 1} {@creature giant spider|mm|giant spiders} hidden in the trees.

A bandit's net trap has been laid across the trail and covered with leaves. It can be spotted with a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. If players walk into it, the trap springs, and players must make a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw to avoid getting caught. On a failure, you can roll on this table again to complicate the encounter.
table.name: Appendix E: Random Encounters; Forest Encounters (Level 1-2)

table.caption: Mountain Encounters (Levels 2-3)
rows: Two {@creature griffon|mm|griffons} can be seen in the distance. They give a warning shriek. The party can find another route, losing ground and rolling again on this table, or fight them.
{@dice 1d4} {@creature mapach bandit|HWCS|mapach bandits} and a {@creature vulpin captain|HWCS} attack.

The weather suddenly shifts to a bitter storm. If the party chooses not to take shelter, they must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw while traveling, suffering a level of {@condition exhaustion} from the cold on a failure.

The party finds a weathered shrine to Altus. The first character that stops to pray here gains the ability to cast {@spell enhance ability} once, without using material components. The player may only select either the {@b Bear's Endurance} or {@b Bull's Strength} options when the spell is cast.

The party finds a roost of {@dice 1d3} {@creature giant eagle|mm|giant eagles} with {@dice 1d4} young (Medium sized beasts that cannot attack) with them. They will attack unless the party can convince them they are not a threat.
table.name: Appendix E: Random Encounters; Mountain Encounters (Levels 2-3)

table.caption: Scorched Grove Encounters (Level 3)
rows: {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature swarm of emberbats|HWCS|swarms of emberbats} attack.
An {@creature ashsnake|HWCS} attacks. If the party is hunting for the ashsnake in {@adventure Part 3|HWAitW|3}, it is waiting to ambush them.

The party finds a small stand of scorched trees, two of which tower above the others. When approached these two {@creature awakened tree|mm|awakened trees} attack with branches that glow with embers. Their attacks deal fire damage instead of bludgeoning damage, and can set flammable objects carried by characters on fire.
One {@creature fire elemental} can be seen off in the distance. Players must make a DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check to avoid its notice, otherwise it will see them and attack.
{@dice 1d3} {@creature magma mephit|mm|magma mephits} and {@dice 1d2} {@creature dust mephit|mm|dust mephits} attack.
A Tender is being attacked by a {@creature swarm of emberbats|HWCS}.

A field of geysers lays ahead, each intermittently spraying scalding gases into the air. The party can attempt to cross cautiously with a DC 16 Intelligence check to notice a pattern, or by making three DC 14 Dexterity saving throws, taking 4 ({@dice 1d8}) fire damage on each failure. Pass or fail, after 3 saving throws they've made it across. Alternatively, party members can choose to go around. If so, roll again on this table.
table.name: Appendix E: Random Encounters; Scorched Grove Encounters (Level 3)

table.caption: Swamp Encounters (Level 1)
rows: {@dice 1d3} {@creature birdfolk skeleton|HWCS|birdfolk skeletons}, covered in moss rise from the murky water and attack.
Two {@creature sticky slime|HWCS|sticky slimes} and a {@creature caustic slime|HWCS} attack.
The party stumbles upon a {@creature swarm of quippers} in the water. Players with a passive Perception of 15 or higher notice the swarm and avoid it.

The party finds a fungus covered shrine to Henwin within a tangle of plant life. The first character to pray here gains the ability to cast {@spell spiny shield|HWCS} once, without using material components.
{@dice 1d2} {@creature swarm of insects|MM|swarms of insects} envelop the party. They have a walking speed of 5 ft., a 30 ft. flying speed, and no climbing speed.
A birdfolk researcher caught in quicksand. Requires a DC 12 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to free. Roll again on this table to complicate the encounter.
table.name: Appendix E: Random Encounters; Swamp Encounters (Level 1)

table.caption: What did They Find?
rows: A carefully cleaned and varnished mouse skull.
A ruby statue worth 50 gp, but birdfolk and humblefolk alike believe it to be cursed.
A golden coin dating back to the very founding of Alderheart.
A small switch-knife hidden inside of a wooden spoon.
A holy symbol of an Amaranthine not worshiped in Humblewood.
A feather with brilliant tropical colors, not seen on any Humblewood birdfolk.
A ring with a strange seed where a gemstone would normally be.
A mechanical cricket, but its winding key is missing.
A thin length of chain, that when examined is actually made of seamless loops of wood.
A small bag containing hand polished marbles, each one with a different small insect in it.
A necklace made from the shells of small iridescent beetles.
A wooden frog that is perpetually slick with some kind of viscous moisture.
A short, thin twig that is unbendable and indestructible.
A locket made from a polished periwinkle shell. A strange sigil has been carved on the inside.
A glass jar filled with eight fireflies, each giving off light. One glows white, and the others glow a different color of the rainbow.
A bandit mask from a time before the Coalition.
A detailed onyx carving of a birdfolk skull. It is cold to the touch.
A silver pinecone that is completely immune to fire damage.
A locked music box. Mechanical chirping can occasionally be heard from inside.
A weathered parchment scroll, which unfurls to reveal music inscribed in long-faded ink.
table.name: Appendix F: What did They Find?; What did They Find?

Three werewolves howling at the moon
A snaking piece of barbed wire
table.name: Fast Franchise Generator; Franchise Logos or Livery

table.caption: Headquarters Locations
rows: A tavern once owned by smugglers. Tunnel entrances have clearly been bricked over, and no one's quite sure where they all lead.
A simple chapel to a long-forgotten god. The pews are awfully uncomfortable, but fragrant incense burns without ceasing.
A battle-worn castle. A real fixer-upper, it's seen better days. Better years. Maybe even better centuries.
A top-of-the-line naval vessel that has somehow been stranded miles inland.
A private library. The franchise is free to use the space as long as no harm comes to the books.
A hollowed-out statue of an ancient king.
An early model airship. Very early. The balloon is mostly patches at this point—a motley assortment of ship sails, cloaks, and animal skins.
A former blacksmith's shop, which was a former exercise studio, and a former cafe before that.
A multicolor waterproof canvas stretched over a succession of jutting stone columns. Within, it always appears to be late spring.
A creaking wagon that smells of turnips, and which is bigger inside than out.
table.name: Fast Franchise Generator; Headquarters Locations

table.caption: Headquarters Quirks
rows: One staircase leads to two different places somehow.
Any kettle used in the kitchen screams when it boils.
Every chair has one leg slightly shorter than the others.
Every stairwell has an illusion of one additional step at the top.
There's a nest in the attic. A big nest. Like, really big.
Every Friday, the color of the walls changes to a different festive theme.
The building was previously owned by a franchise rival, and the place is filled with their marketing materials.
There's a space inside the headquarters that's clearly a room, but which has no doors.
table.name: Fast Franchise Generator; Headquarters Quirks

table.caption: Memorable Majordomos
rows: A consummate professional. No amount of blood, gore, or viscera will keep them from completing their duties.
A sinister figure who sticks to the shadows and respond always to requests with, "Yes, master."
The ghost of the previous owner. They do a terrible job and refer to all prospective clients as trespassers.
A brusque, deaf, retired military captain.
An incredibly cheerful chef, who insists that no business is more pressing than a full belly.
A druid that keeps an open door policy for any and all animals seeking shelter. Their cleaning policy is less rigorous.
table.name: Fast Franchise Generator; Memorable Majordomos

table.caption: Reliable Connections
rows: {@b Kim the Kid}: The best fence in town.
{@b Jeremy Snoot}: The most easily intimidated customs official in the city. From blueprints of government buildings to shipping manifests, he's your halfling.
{@b York Battleby}: A dab hand at knitting and swinging a sword. He takes payment in liquor for either service.
{@b Diana Fenwick}: Noble who wants to play criminal; enthusiastic, inexperienced, and loaded.
{@b "G"}: The only thing known about this information broker is the dead-drop point where they exchange messages, and that they're never wrong.
{@b Teresa Clearlake}: If you're looking for a place to lie low, her funeral home is ideal.
{@b Jenkin Twotooth}: Always has a job for those looking to scrape together a few coins. Unfortunately, his teeth outnumber his scruples.
{@b "Mustard" Micah}: Famous for being able to get goods and people past any blockade. Provided you don't mind said goods or people smelling strongly of mustard for the next month.
table.name: Fast Franchise Generator; Reliable Connections

"The Last Resting Place of My Rich Brother that is Also a Bear Cave"
A range of peaks known as the Slightly Wobbly Spires
An ever-flowing, nonmagical spigot of pure, clear water in the middle of nowhere
A cave filled with screaming bioluminescent worms
The most haunted forest for ten miles in any direction
A huge pile of rocks with no other rocks within sight
table.name: Map of the Moment; Possible Map Mission Landmarks

table.caption: Why Be a Cartographer?
rows: A paranoid person by nature, you like seeing what's ahead of you at all times.
Your parent was a cartographer, their parent was a cartographer, and by the gods, you're going to be one too.
You're fairly certain no one else in your party even knows how to hold a map, let alone read one.
Your nickname as a child was "the cartography kid."
Contrary to popular opinion, the destination is much, much more important than the journey.
A good map is like an adventure without the bugs. And the mud. And the wolves.
You suffer from the nagging feeling of never knowing why you've come into a room, and you need the professional flourish that lets you cover for that.
table.name: Why Be a Cartographer?

table.caption: Coin of Decisionry "Tails" Image
rows: A fourteen-headed hydra (it's a big coin)
An old despotic tyrant, their image defaced
table.name: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment; Coin of Decisionry "Tails" Image

table.caption: Why Be a Decisionist?
rows: It's always you who picks where everyone has lunch.
Roughly half your choices are the right ones. You might as well just toss a coin for it.
You have no idea. In fact, you're constantly plagued by indecision.
Democracy is the greatest force for change in the world, but is ruined by everyone else voting.
All the other positions were taken.
You've always felt it was your calling to tell other people what to do. Now to make it official.
When faced with two choices, you've always yearned for the freedom to choose both.
As a child, you had a sibling make you choose which of your toys lived or died. You were never the same.
table.name: Why Be a Decisionist?

table.caption: Favorite Methods to Destroy Documents
rows: Any way you like, provided you make a copy first
The bottomless hole in the basement—at least you're pretty sure it's bottomless
Feeding it to the goat out back
Making your coworkers eat it by slipping it into their food, piece by piece—it's the only way to be sure
table.name: Documancer; Favorite Methods to Destroy Documents

table.caption: The Documancer
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, Gift of Words
table.name: The Documancer

table.caption: Why Be a Documancer?
rows: You heard a rumor once that signing a contract with your off hand is technically nonbinding, and you're desperate to see if it's true. For reasons.
All businesses have their ups and downs, but there's always money to be made from "processing fees."
You have a habit of always being clear about what you've promised, but never saying when you'll do it.
You love doing decorative scrollwork on documents, knowing that's the best place to hide the fine print.
As a child, you learned to cross your fingers behind your back when making a promise. Now you yearn to make that legally binding.
Your habit of screaming, "No take backs!" after any group decision seemed to suggest your true calling.
You believe that language is an art, not a science. Who's to say what is or isn't a "real" word?
The smell of old parchment makes you giddy.
table.name: Why Be a Documancer?

table.caption: The Hoardsperson
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, What a Deal
{@item Living Loot Satchel|AI}, Living the Good Life
Secret Satchel, That Thing You Need
Portable Hole Satchel, That Expensive Thing You Need
table.name: The Hoardsperson

table.caption: Class-Based Living Loot Satchel
rows: Broad belt with a dozen hanging pockets
Made from natural, organic, locally sourced woven fibers
A metal case with fine engraving and scrollwork
A battered leather satchel, prone to spitting out multicolored sparks at the seams
A patchwork monster-leather satchel with a "purely decorative" fanged mouth.
A pocket dimension hidden up your sleeve or inside your hat
table.name: Class-Based Living Loot Satchel

table.caption: Why Be a Hoardsperson?
rows: You once tried to dive into a huge pool of gold coins. It hurt.
You've been betrayed by your adventuring party before, and there's no way now that you'll trust anyone else to hold on to the loot
Once, through a series of increasingly complex negotiations, you traded a paper clip for temporary control of a minor fiefdom.
Material possessions don't mean that much to you. Or at least that's the story you're going with.
You've never had a problem spending other people's money. Surely keeping other people's money can't be that hard.
You believe there's no such thing as worthless goods. Only unmotivated buyers.
You're not a hoarder. More of a passionate collector. You can stop anytime you want. Really.
Given the personalities of the other party members, it was mutually agreed that you were the only one who could be trusted
table.name: Why Be a Hoardsperson?

table.caption: The Loremonger
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, {@item Whisper Jar|AI}
table.name: The Loremonger

table.caption: Things Recorded in Your Whisper Jar
rows: A live recording of the only performance of the mostly forgotten stage play {@i Tabaxi on a Hot Tin Roof}
The life's work of the loremonger who owned the jar before you
Every courageous thought you've ever had, to cover for how scared you are most of the time
Everything, because everyone else around you will eat their words one day!
The top seven places to eat fried rat skewers in every settlement you've ever visited
The entire family tree of every royal line, extant or lost, in Faerûn
A moment-by-moment review of your favorite {@creature Jim Darkmagic|AI} stage performance
The sound of raucous applause, which you play back liberally
table.name: Things Recorded in Your Whisper Jar

table.caption: Why Be a Loremonger?
rows: Your favorite thing to hear is, "I probably shouldn't say anything, but did you know... ?"
Your {@i whisper jar} is a better conversationalist than most people you've ever met.
You can't keep a secret for the life of you, and you need to tell someone this thing you know or it's going to kill you!
You never know when someone else's words will come in handy.
Peoples and cultures can never die as long as their stories are still told.
You talked about a really cool idea once when you were drunk, and can't remember a word of it now. That'll never happen again.
A person is only as good as their word, and you feel compelled to keep others honest.
You can't read or write, so this whole recording-and-playing-back-what-you-say-in-a-jar thing is a huge benefit.
table.name: Why Be a Loremonger?

table.caption: The Obviator
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, Read the Opposition
table.name: The Obviator

table.caption: Where You First Dabbled in Alchemy
rows: You traveled with a charlatan alchemist for years, until they were arrested for selling fake healing potions. You still remember how to get the taste just right.
You were once the head dishwasher in a famous wizard's college.
One of your parents was a healer in a small outpost, and they taught you that even the most mundane flora and natural materials can be used to wondrous effect.
While lost in the Underdark, you were forced to consume mold, fungus, and insect parts to survive. You developed a taste for that sort of thing.
You think you might be addicted to holy water. You just can't stop drinking it long enough to find out for sure.
You were once the personnel manager of a struggling business and needed to come up with a herbal cure-all that would keep employees awake for eighteen-hour shifts. No one died. Mostly.
As the child of a wealthy and despotic noble, you learned to smell {@condition poisoned} pastries a mile off. A shame that your siblings weren't so talented.
As a server in a tavern, you refined the perfect hangover cure but never wrote the recipe down. Now you're desperate to recreate it.
table.name: Alchemist's Insight; Where You First Dabbled in Alchemy

table.caption: Why Be an Obviator?
rows: There's nothing that excites you more than a puzzle you can't immediately solve.
Your favorite saying is, "All according to plan." Especially when you have no idea what's going on.
You have an entire room dedicated to notes and sketches connected by red yarn.
Your plans are so detailed that they have plans of their own.
You find the little details so much more interesting than... well, anything else.
You already had the chemical burns on your hands. Might as well make it official.
Methodical. Calculating. Brilliant. One day, you hope these words will apply to you.
It's not paranoia if they really are out to get you. And if you're out to get them first.
table.name: Why Be an Obviator?

table.caption: The Occultant
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, Read the Kill
Eldritch Occultant, Bring Out Your Dead
Bead of Instant Karma, Death's Omen
Bead of Diverted Karma, Correct the Balance
table.name: The Occultant

table.caption: Ways to Read the Kill
rows: Using a tiny bellows to pump one last breath into a corpse.
Reading the entrails with special reading-the-entrails glasses.
Burning a small piece of the body and looking for shapes in the smoke.
Careful measurements. The distance between nostrils. The difference between the index finger and the middle finger. The elasticity of the ear lobe.
You take a long, careful look, and then decide based on which fellow franchisee has been nice to you lately.
table.name: Ways to Read the Kill

table.caption: Why Be an Occultant?
rows: You believe in karmic balance, but hate the idea that "balance" means good and bad things can both happen to you. Good things happening to you and bad things happening to other people seems perfectly reasonable.
You love drinking tea and hate cleaning up, so pretending that the dregs in those dozens of empty cups are there to show ill omens and portents is a perfect cover.
You collected beads carved as skulls as a child. Nobody ever told you there was a career in that sort of thing.
You watched someone close to you die, and were overcome by the feeling that you should be making money off it somehow.
You've always owned a stuffed cat. You're not sure where it came from, but it's given you great career advice so far.
You've always worn a lot of black.
You really wanted a job where you can hide a fog machine under the desk for dramatic effect during meetings.
You have an obsession with death that clearly marks you for great things.
table.name: Why Be an Occultant?

table.caption: The Secretarian
rows: Proficiencies and Starting Equipment, {@item Sending Stone|AI}
Cards of Sending, Improved Rumor Mill
table.name: The Secretarian

table.caption: Quirks of Your Sending Stone
rows: It gets great reception everywhere except in your headquarters.
It sometimes picks up other magical conversations.
It's the perfect size, shape, and weight to be used as a skipping stone.
It heats up when you use it, to the extent that it once burned through your gloves.
It has an obnoxious ringtone that you can't work out how to change.
It fails to notify you of incoming messages except for a faint pulsating glow.
It's voice activated, so that every time you talk to someone, it tries to send a message to someone else.
table.name: Quirks of Your Sending Stone

table.caption: Why Be a Secretarian?
rows: You believe that people shouldn't work harder; they should work smarter. And then they should work harder.
You've always yearned to be in the people business, because inanimate objects can't pay you.
Being able to hand out "Employee of the Month" stickers has been a life-long dream.
You believe that customer loyalty can't be bought, but that it can be rented at reasonable terms and rates.
Your habit of constantly telling other people how they can improve makes you a master of performance reviews.
You've always believed that the customer is satisfied when you say the customer is satisfied, and not a second before.
You love the joy that other people get when you tell them what to do.
table.name: Why Be a Secretarian?

table.caption: Signature Items
rows: A tooth from a previous victim, wrapped in a silk handkerchief
A calling card with your name on it
A quick charcoal sketch of your victim, done in your own hand
Six drops of blood, either your own or someone else's
A carved ivory die with an eye instead of a pip on the 1 face
A copper coin bearing the likeness of a reaper
A tiny vial containing a few drops of the homemade ale you're so proud of
An IOU, accompanied by you taking something from the victim
table.name: Sending a Clear Message; Signature Items

table.caption: Barbarian Style
rows: A fur-lined, double-breasted suit with a corporate logo on the pocket
A hand-woven turban from a master tailor of Calimshan
Soft leather boots with a notable personal symbol etched into the side
A pair of suspenders made from the hide of a displacer beast
A gold belt buckle depicting the Dwarvish rune for chaos
A specially tailored belt pouch that you wear at the small of your back
A specially dyed tunic containing all the colors of the rainbow in a swirled pattern
An overcoat with numerous pockets and leather patches on the elbows
Golden grillwork for your teeth, set with small gems that mark out ancient glyphs translating as "Getting Paid"
table.name: Barbarian Style

rows: A half-orc enforcer called Joey Plantain, missing his right arm
A disgraced tax collector named Nibbin Clutchquill
An overly enthusiastic morale liaison called Apricot Reese
A grumpy dwarf carriage driver nicknamed Bolt
A pair of identical twin circus performers called Stella and Bella
An elf bodyguard known as Mistress Leafwind
table.name: Path of the Ancestral Guardian

table.caption: Insults to Die For
rows: Did your mother have any children who lived?
You smell like a hell hound's hindquarters.
You're as helpful as a halfling.
Let me guess. You're a self-taught wizard?
Your personality has all the warmth of a winter wolf.
You're the loveliest hag in the coven.
You're not the sharpest piercer in the cave.
Aren't you a little short for a giant?
Truly, your intellect is as deep as a {@spell Tenser's floating disk}.
Did you wake up in a troglodyte den this morning, or is that how you normally smell?
You must have been sick the day they taught fighting at warrior school.
Gruumsh must have closed his eye when he created you.
I can see you, but where's the dragon that pooped you out?
You've got all the good sense of a mind flayer's last meal.
You don't know a beholder from a gas spore.
I suspected you'd fallen out of the idiot tree, but I didn't know you were dragged through Stupid Forest afterward.
There's nothing about your looks that a full-face helmet wouldn't improve.
You're about as useful as an orc horde at a tea party.
I've seen better-looking faces on a gibbering mouther.
table.name: Cutting Wit and Wicked Barbs; Insults to Die For

table.caption: Notable Enemies
rows: A guard captain who was fired for failing to catch you after you flouted the law
A former master bard whose songs you stole and knowledge you plundered
A lesser noble who you double-crossed in a brilliant scheme
A fallen paladin who you tricked into breaking their oath
A leader of another adventuring party who blames you for their downfall
A former adventuring partner who you cut loose because of their lack of skill
The master of a powerful guild whose wares you were involved in pilfering
A government official who you tricked into providing secrets
A former tavern owner who lost their business when you implicated them in a scheme they weren't actually involved in
A moneylender who you inadvertently bankrupted
table.name: The Wrong Kind of People; Notable Enemies

table.caption: Relics of Faith
rows: Unexpurgated holy texts with all the really naughty bits (10 gp)
table.name: Divine Deals; Relics of Faith

table.caption: Meditative Rituals
rows: Handwriting a detailed agenda for the next 24 hours
Sitting in silence for 15 minutes, while screaming "Shut up!" at anyone who makes noise
Sleep another hour; your deity says it's fine
Burning incense and lighting a candle on a makeshift altar while you recite your vows
Creating a new likeness of your deity out of whatever materials you have on hand
Drinking a lot of wine (sacramental, of course)
table.name: Clerical Routine; Meditative Rituals

table.caption: Relationship with Your Deity
rows: Your deity possesses you and speaks through your lips, and you need someone else to take notes.
You see your deity's signs in the movements of creatures, the changing weather, the shapes of buildings, other stuff.
In secret, you curse the burden your deity has placed on you.
You wonder often if you're worthy of your deity's gifts.
You're convinced your deity isn't all-knowing, because they clearly have no idea what you really get up to.
Your deity gives you power and you give them glory—at any cost.
Those other clerics don't love your deity like you do.
You were raised religious, but you only really go to church on the high holidays.
Your deity's grace gives you peace. Their anger drives your fury.
You've got buyer's remorse, and you're wondering if this is really the deity for you.
table.name: The Ways of Faith; Relationship with Your Deity

table.caption: Distinguishing Features of Wild Shape
rows: Your pelt is rich hues of gold and silver so bright that they reflect light.
When you take wild shape form, it's a painful, squelchy process that usually leaves your fellow adventurers queasy.
Your wild shape forms all wear an identical ceremonial bracelet on one limb, decorated with teeth.
A dark patch on your body is recognizable as the silhouette of {@creature Omin Dran|AI}
You always have twigs, leaves, and other refuse tangled in your fur or hair.
When you switch back to your normal form, one hand always manages to retain its fur or feathers for a short while.
table.name: Running Wild; Distinguishing Features of Wild Shape

table.caption: Urban Sanctuaries
rows: A cemetery that acts as a de facto park
A museum hosting rare plants and animals from other lands
A swampy patch, unsuitable for building, teeming with marsh flora and fauna
A large copse containing the habitats of tree-dwelling animals
A community garden whose bounty is shared by local residents
A ruined section of the city that has been reclaimed by nature
A zoo overseen by a strange but powerful fellow druid
A private park that charges a fee for entrance, ensuring that only the wealthy can enjoy its serenity
A nature reserve stocked with scared and confused animals that are hunted for sport
A business that grows and harvests rare and exotic plants and animals for creating magical and mundane products
table.name: Nature in Unlikely Places; Urban Sanctuaries

table.caption: Creatures to Care For
rows: A carnivorous plant with a taste for fine foods
A colony of bees whose hive once hung from a tree in your homeland
A seven-legged pygmy giant spider once used as a pixie's mount
A baby death dog that shows no evil tendencies (yet)
An orphaned owlbear cub-chick with a never-ending cold
An unhatched silvery egg that is ice-cold to the touch
A very small, very old awakened shrub
A grouchy badger that lives under your bed
A feral cat that thinks it's much tougher than it is
A friendly stirge that nests in your backpack and drinks only fruit juice
table.name: Steward of Nature; Creatures to Care For

table.caption: Martial Tricks
rows: You are an expert at pretending you've been injured to the point where you can't possibly go on. By goading foes to finish you off, you keep your allies safe as you reveal how much fight you still have in you.
You always keep a small pouch of salt or sand at your belt. If you can blind an opponent, even momentarily, you can usually end a fight quickly.

You fight with your off hand at the start of a battle, so that your opponent sets their defenses and attacks to one side. Then you quickly switch hands at the most opportune moment, making your foe wonder what other tricks you might play.
Swearing, name-calling, political satire—you do it all. You make use of a range of down-and-dirty fighting epithets that would make an ogre barbarian blush.

You constantly converse with your opponents during the battle, doing whatever you can to distract them or get into their heads. It's surprising how many combatants enter a fight not knowing whether their boots have come untied.
You have a belt pouch specially made to release ball bearings or caltrops in the thick of the fight, forcing your enemies to avoid those hazards while fending off your blows.
table.name: Keeping them Guessing; Martial Tricks

table.caption: Signature Equipment
rows: Handcrafted arrows whose heads bear the mark of a lightning bolt, and which give a distinctive whistle when fired
A shield made from the shell of a giant turtle
A matching shortsword and dagger, decorated to look like the upper and lower jaws of a carnivorous dinosaur
A battleaxe with its head shaped like the flowing hair of a dwarf warrior
A suit of armor made from the discarded chitin of giant arthropods
A pair of boots fashioned to look like the paws of a large feline
A sword whose pommel is shaped in the form of a hand, so that you shake the hand when you wield it
A hammer forged to resemble a giant's fist on one side and a dragon's head on the other
A helmet shaped like the head of a hare, with tiny diamonds for eyes
A bow carved with images of the phases of the moon
A dagger with a handle made of bone, etched with worn and unreadable runes
A backpack made from the leather and fur of a skunk
table.name: Wielding the Best; Signature Equipment

table.caption: Victory Celebration
rows: Seizing a trophy from a vanquished foe
Composing a poem extolling your valiant combat prowess
Adding a commemorative square to your battle quilt
Adding a decorative stencil to your favorite weapon or armor
Paying the town crier to proclaim your victory
Commissioning a painting of the battle
Praising surviving enemies for a job well done, no hard feelings
There is no time to celebrate, for your war is eternal!
table.name: Victory Is Yours; Victory Celebration

table.caption: Subtle Stances
rows: Incontinent Elder—Standing straight, knees together (excellent for surviving those long queues)
Addled Adder—Lying flat on the ground (perfect when attempting to hide)
Ponderous Pudding—Collapsed in a heap (useful when trying to disguise yourself as a drunken fool)
Frightened Gnome—Curled in the fetal position (excellent when about to take a lot of damage)
Ambitious Student—Standing with one armed raised (useful when trying to be seen)
Boisterous Brewmaster—Hand raised as if making a toast (excellent at preventing being slapped)
Hardy Harpy—Arms flapping wildly while singing (inspires people to leave you alone, and good for cooling off on hot days)
Broken Bridge—Face down on the ground with knees bent and posterior up (reduces visibility to foes in front, and makes a useful ramp for allies to jump off)
table.name: Stances for Success; Subtle Stances

table.caption: Ancient Tomes
rows: {@i The Organic Sun and Moon Cookbook}
{@i Life is Endless Calamities, What Are You Going to Do About It}?
table.name: By the Book; Ancient Tomes

table.caption: Commercial Monasteries
rows: Monastery of the Eternal Spirits (legendary distillers)
House of the Upright Arches (creators of quality footwear)
Dome of the Curious Quill (makers of parchment, ink, and writing quills)
Crystal Bastion (makers of crystal goblets and ornaments)
Monastery Actuary (underwriters of reasonably priced insurance policies)
House of Hot Ki (delicious barbecue take-out)
Monastery of the Wayward Grape (vintners of fine wines)
Spider's House Retreat (drow trainers of giant spiders as mounts and companions)
table.name: Ascetic Business Practices; Commercial Monasteries

table.caption: Terrible Secrets
rows: Before taking your paladin oath, you accidentally publicly humiliated a good friend. You have sworn to make it up to them, despite them wanting nothing to do with you.

You took another person's identity to escape the law in your younger days—and quickly came to realize that this person was far cooler than the real you. If anyone finds out your true identity, your reputation will suffer.

You were the child of nobles who were found guilty of stealing vast sums from their subjects. If your identity is discovered, you might be hunted down. But you might also be in line for a massive inheritance.

You once belonged to an organization that was eventually banned because a typo in its name made it appear seditious. If anyone discovers this, you run the risk of being mistaken for an enemy of the realm.

You made a deal with a fiendish creature to escape trouble or save another character's life. Emissaries of this fiend appear occasionally to tell you that the paperwork regarding the debt you owe is temporarily lost, but they're working on it.
You owe an enormous amount of money to a forgetful and amoral person. So far, that person has made no sign of wanting you to repay the debt, and you have no idea what to do about that.
table.name: Things Best Left Unsaid; Terrible Secrets

table.caption: Legendary Catchphrases
rows: Looks like this is the end. So let's go back to the beginning.
There's only one way out of this pickle, and that's by breaking a few jars!
Looks like trouble has some vacation time coming up. So let's book it a nice inn.
We've got a real game of cat and mouse here... so it's time to eat some cheese.
It's always darkest before the dawn, except when the moon is full. So let's moon!
We might be beaten, but we're not beaten! Because "beaten" means different things in both those contexts!
"Surrender" is my middle name, but it was a family thing and I never use it!
table.name: Fixer of Problems; Legendary Catchphrases

table.caption: Urban Beast Friends
table.name: Animals are Everywhere; Urban Beast Friends

table.caption: Disguised Weapons
rows: The roasted drumstick of a huge bird (greatclub; longsword if a shard of bone is broken off)
A long loaf of stale bread (mace)
A musical instrument missing all but one string (shortbow)
A racket used in a popular sport (handaxe, battleaxe)
A large bottle of wine (mace, shortsword if shattered)
table.name: No Weapons Allowed; Disguised Weapons

table.caption: Points of Interest
rows: A secret cove a few hours' north of town that is a known meeting spot for pirates.
A sewer system underneath the local guardhouse.
The quaint settlement where you grew up, and where you send most of what you earn adventuring.
A caravan of merchants and sellswords that follows a regular route across the land.
A temple built to honor a dark god, long abandoned.
The final resting place of the ranger who trained you.
The shady market known as Gort Jorkle's Afflicted Finery, openly and proudly selling the most illegal things imaginable.
An unnamed hill where a ruined tower appears at midnight, then vanishes again at dawn.
table.name: Places to Go; Points of Interest

table.caption: Favorite Trophies
rows: The handkerchief of a noble's paramour, with their initials sewn into it as well as the date and the place the gift was given. Perfect blackmail fodder.
A silver goblet from the kitchens of a castle in a wealthy land. It still smells of the wonderful burgundy that was in it when you stole it.
A gold-tipped fountain pen stolen from the breast pocket of a royal wizard.
A piece of intricately woven curtain you had to cut to escape a mayor's manor after stealing their valuables.
A gray cat with white feet, once the pet of a rich merchant's spoiled child. She almost blew your cover. Now she knows when to keep quiet, and she's great at catching mice.
A small statue of a ballerina, broken off from a marble fountain in a city from which you're now banned.
A serpentine lapel pin set with tiny diamonds, which you slipped off the chest of a noble whose fete you finessed your way into.
The solid-gold hammer holy symbol of that one rude blacksmith who refused to fix your sword.
A full potion bottle from the temple of Oghma, marked "Drink in case of emergency." So far, no one has dared you to drink it.
A cracked mirror from a mystic's tower, which sometimes shows you a glint of another realm in one of its shards.
table.name: Sign of Success; Favorite Trophies

table.caption: Former Guilds
rows: The Tumble Dumplings, an all-halfling guild whose cover identities are acrobats
The Char Hawks, whose front operation is a well-known cleaning service
The Flattering Butchers, known for their sales of discount meat of unknown provenance
The Profane Pilferers, who leave lewd calling cards at the scenes of their crimes
The Undead Rangers, whose cover is that they have nothing to do with rangers or the undead
The Loyalists, ironically known for breaking contracts at an alarming rate
The Robust Vultures, who make use of flying magic for specialty jobs
The Quick and the Fred, who all use "Fred" as an alias
table.name: Old Business Ties; Former Guilds

table.caption: Unusual Arcane Focuses
rows: A stuffed weasel with fake diamonds for eyes
A rare gold coin that sparkles as you cast
A copper belt buckle created in your own likeness
A pair of silver spectacles whose lenses change color based on the school of spell you're casting
A well-preserved sausage that smells delicious to you and any other creature nearby
A gold harmonica that cranks out a dramatic tune when you cast
A shrunken gnome head that blinks and sticks its tongue out occasionally
A polo mallet carved in the shape of the tarrasque
A flask of liquid that changes color each time you cast
The antler stub of a peryton, decorated with nymph hair and pixie dust
table.name: Focusing with Flair; Unusual Arcane Focuses

table.caption: Residual Magic
rows: A smell just slightly less noxious than troglodyte musk wafts off you from time to time.
At random, your voice shifts three octaves higher or lower than normal.
Your hair changes color for 1 hour. If you don't have hair, you grow silver hair that lasts for 1 hour, then falls out.
At random, your speech and movement suggest that you are blind drunk.
Your eyes glow for 1 minute, cycling intermittently through red, blue, and green.
Sometimes when you deal damage to a creature, a disembodied voice near you shouts out, "Boo yah!"
Blood momentarily drips from your ears and eyes.
Your fingernails grow out to gnarled talons. This new growth falls off after 10 minutes or if you touch something.
Intermittently, any somatic components for spells you cast take the form of violent coughing.
For 1 minute, you are 6 inches shorter or taller than normal.
table.name: Personal Magic; Residual Magic

table.caption: Otherworldly Quirks
rows: Every meal you eat must involve copious amounts of raw onions.
When you are in a stressful situation, you shout every fourth word you speak.
You have a second set of ears that emerge and retract whenever you are actively listening.
You can't bear to touch anything valuable without wearing gloves.
When you wash or bathe, anything less than uncomfortably hot water feels cold to you.
You have to slap some creature roughly before you can get a good night's sleep.
You're just not comfortable unless your clothing features garishly contrasting colors or patterns.
When you cast a spell, the verbal or somatic component must involve a mild obscenity.
Your hair grows so quickly that you must cut it during every short or long rest.
When people call you by your correct name, you constantly admonish them by telling them your correct name.
table.name: Eldritch Affectations; Otherworldly Quirks

table.caption: Cool Mottos
rows: "I don't break even; I get even."
"I'm the prophet of profit, and I've got a prediction for success."
"Victory is the finest perfume, and I smell delightful."
"To err is human, so I'm not."
"I get the job done rather than thinking up fancy mottos."
table.name: Marketing Is Everything; Cool Mottos

table.caption: Lingering Nightmares
rows: You stand atop a cliff as an apocalyptic sea monster emerges and begins painting the world around you with a brush in each tentacle. You cannot escape its attention, but wake up just before you are recolored.
You dream about walking on pieces of paper, each of which is scribed with the word "eggshells." This is written in multiple languages, some of which you can't read.

You are giving the most important presentation of your career, and the magic you are using to create an impressive visual display has gone haywire. It now displays an illusory image of you wearing nothing but a strategically placed scarf.

A franchise staff member has gained a huge inheritance and retired. A note signed by you indicates that you withdrew the same huge amount of cash from company accounts the day before, but you have no memory of doing so.
You feel the pleasant tickling of feathers, then look up to find a cockatrice preening on your chest.
All your pockets have been torn open, but you can't stop placing valuable objects in them. Each time an object falls out of a pocket, you pick it up, then put it in a pocket again.
table.name: Nightmare Magic; Lingering Nightmares

table.caption: Arcane Masters
rows: Philia Fjor, a half-elf abjurer who baked cupcakes that functioned as potions.
Oghhga, a mute half-orc diviner who beat her unsuccessful students to death with rocks.
Impler Rickys, a gnome transmuter who lived under a bridge and worked for candied beets and honey peanuts.
Dame Melna Rothburntonberryville, a 238-year-old elf croquet player and evoker, and hero of the first, second, third, fifth, and sixth Troll Wars. (She was out on maternity leave during the fourth.)
Fernstern Drockburn, a deep gnome ventriloquist and conjurer, and his "dummy" Vinceroy, an imp familiar in a puppet suit.
Loa Hatt, a tiefling illusionist and cobbler, whose rumored dealings with devils led to many jokes about fixing soles while destroying souls.
Reni the Hare, a halfling enchanter with an odd fondness for carrots. You ate a lot of carrots as an apprentice. You don't much like carrots anymore.

Sylvester Delague, a human necromancer whose greatest possession was a portrait painted by an ex-student, said to capture his green eyes perfectly. In truth, Sylvester was color-blind, and the portrait's eyes are bloodshot red. No one ever told him.
table.name: Learning from the Best; Arcane Masters

rows: A ghostly hand appears and slaps a random character for {@dice 2d4} bludgeoning damage. If this kills them, they rise as a spectral presence that follows the group, endlessly slapping them as well.
Five {@creature Giant Rat||giant rats} burst from the ground and attack. Name them after your favorite boy band.
Every magic potion the party carries has turned to spoiled milk.
Point at the character who last spoke. Their left foot has fallen asleep, causing them to suffer {@b −}1 Dexterity for an hour.
Two {@creature Flameskull||flameskulls} fly in, accompanied by loud heavy metal music. They attack.
A lone {@creature flameskull} flies in, looking for his two friends who ditched him on the way to a heavy metal concert. He's confused and angry and also attacks.
The party hears a scraping noise coming from the nearby wall. Make it seem important to the story. Use this noise to focus the group and lead them to the next encounter.
A random character vomits up an {@creature ochre jelly}. Describe the burning sensation as it erupts from the character's feeble mouth-hole. Make the party regret ever wasting your time.
A random character's favorite weapon just gained magical intelligence and starts nagging them about getting on with the adventure.
An arrow suddenly shoots out from the shadows and hits the character who is pissing you off. The character takes {@dice 1d6 + 4} piercing damage and should reconsider their current course of action.
Something gold and shiny catches the eye of a party member. What is it? Whatever you want.
Pick a random character. Tell them their esophagus is cursed.
table.name: Surprise

rows: If you made this roll during an attack, you just hit a random character with double critical damage instead. If this roll was non-combat, you're so angry at f***ing up that you attack a random character with your primary weapon in frustration.
Give the die that made this roll to another player at the table. They must use this die for the rest of the game session and, every time they roll it, they have to say "Bad, die. BAD!"
All your hair falls out. Yes, even down there...
All your magic items have turned into nonmagical versions of the same stuff.
Roll twice on the SURPRISE table from earlier in this chapter.
You take {@dice 1d12} force damage. Describe in excruciating detail what you did to earn this embarrassing injury.
You get a paper cut. If you fail a DC 16 Constitution saving throw, you lose {@dice 1d6} hit points from blood loss at the start of each of your turns for the next {@dice 1d6} rounds.
The weapon or item you were using when you made this crappy roll catches on fire. Throw it away or take {@dice 2d10} fire damage while it smolders.
Whatever you were doing when this roll took place just became a comedic pratfall that hits you in the junk. Take {@dice 2d6} bludgeoning damage, and if you had a point of Inspiration, it's now gone.
You are so angry at your stupid mistake that an important grouping of blood vessels in your brain bursts. Permanently lose 1 Intelligence and your sense of smell.
Your roll was so bad that you forsake the gods. If you're a cleric you poop yourself every time you cast a spell until you finish a long rest.
Your internal organs are replaced with stinging bees. Instant death. No saving throw.
table.name: Critical Hits

footnotes: *You add your Dexterity modifier to your Armor Class when you wear this armor.
table.name: Light Armor

footnotes: **You add your Dexterity modifier, to a maximum of +2, to your Armor Class when you wear this armor.
table.name: Medium Armor

row: {@comic Passed out in the back alley}

table.caption: Standard Languages of Eberron
rows: The Five Nations, trade language of Khorvaire
Darguun, Droaam, Shadow Marches, monsters of Khorvaire
table.name: Standard Languages of Eberron

table.caption: Regrets
rows: While you were serving in the Last War, you were forced to abandon an injured comrade. You don't know if they survived.
You placed your faith in a lover who betrayed you. You don't know if you can ever trust anyone again.
You murdered a rival. Your actions may have been justified, but their face still haunts you.
You made a promise to a child or a lover that you failed to keep.
You squandered your family's fortune and brought shame and ruin to your household.
You made a bargain with an extraplanar entity that you now regret.
You abandoned your family to pursue a life of adventure. Your village was destroyed in the war and you don't know if they survived.
You engaged in covert operations for a nation as a spy or soldier. While you were serving your country, you did unforgivable things.
Someone put their trust in you and you betrayed them for personal gain. You might regret it now, but you can never repair the damage you've done.
You volunteered for mystical experiments. These may be responsible for your class abilities, but you might experience side effects.
table.name: Everyone Has Regrets; Regrets

table.caption: Debts
rows: You committed a crime during the Last War, and now you're being blackmailed by someone who has proof. You can justify your actions, but the law won't care.
You've got a gambling problem. If you can't repay Daask (see {@book chapter 3|ERLW|8|Daask}), you're going to be playing tag with a cockatrice.
You own an uncommon magic item, but you had to sell it to a pawn shop. If you can't reclaim it within the month, they'll sell it off.
You were making a delivery on behalf of the Boromar Clan (see {@book chapter 3|ERLW|8|The Boromar Clan}) and you lost the merchandise.
Someone knows the whereabouts of a sibling or loved one you thought lost in the Mourning, but that information is going to cost you.
You have a degenerative disease that can't be cured by mundane means. If you can't get a lesser restoration soon, you're going to start showing symptoms.
Your family lost everything in the Last War. You could get them a stake in a new farm, inn, or stagecoach with 200 gp.
You've got a price on your head. Until you settle things with House Tharashk, you'd better keep an eye out for bounty hunters.
You have an opportunity to join an influential secret society. But you've got only one month to raise the membership dues.
Roll again. It's not your debt: it's your lover's problem. Can you solve the problem before they have to face the consequences?
table.name: Why Do You Need 200 Gold Pieces?; Debts

table.caption: Healing Services
rows: 3 sp per use of the {@skill Medicine} skill
25 gp per level of the spell
table.name: Medicine; Healing Services

table.caption: Leaving the Mror Holds
rows: A feud with a rival clan has gotten out of hand, and it's best that you spend a few decades away from the Holds while things cool down.
You come from a large family and there's no room for you to shine in your hold, so you hope to make a name for yourself in the wider world.
Your clan has arranged your marriage and your future, and you've decided to have a few adventures before you settle down.
You're pursuing a vendetta with a personal rival, seeking to defeat them either in battle or in business.
You're searching for a legendary dwarven artifact, stolen centuries ago by a Karrnish noble.
You want to assemble champions who can help you explore the ancient ruins beneath your ancestral home.
You've rejected your clan's attitude toward daelkyr magic, earning the enmity of powerful dwarves.
You want to understand how the other peoples of Khorvaire—especially the goblins and orcs—have fought the daelkyr.
table.name: Dwarves of the Mror Holds; Leaving the Mror Holds

table.caption: Zil Schemes
rows: Your family is working on a new form of elemental binding, but they need a lot of Khyber dragonshards.
You have an anonymous contact who sends you missions via the {@spell sending} spell. When you do as you're asked, you receive handsome rewards.
You've inherited a plot of land in Q'barra. If you don't visit within a year, you'll lose the claim.
Due to an unusual twist of Triumvirate law, you share the same name with a number of other Zil, and you're all legally considered to be the same person.
You've acquired a {@item spellshard|ERLW} (described in {@book chapter 5|ERLW|12}) that contains a vast amount of text in a strange code.
You know the location of a wanted war criminal, and you've been trying to decide whether to turn them in or try to get something in exchange for your silence.
You've been selling false treasure maps, but now you've found one that might be real.
You've acquired a controlling stake in a dragonshard mine, which was abandoned long ago. But why? Kobolds? Aberrations? There's only one way to find out!

Your family is facing financial ruin, and they've taken out a life insurance policy on you. It only pays out if you die under unusual circumstances, and they're encouraging you to seek out more dangerous adventures.
You're peddling a life-extension scheme where clients are {@condition petrified} by a medusa and then restored later.
table.name: Gnomes of Zilargo; Zil Schemes

table.caption: Khoravar Origin
rows: You're the linchpin of a Khoravar community in a major city, hosting unity meals and maintaining connections with every half-elf in the city.
You grew up in a small town dominated by humans. You didn't know any other half-elves, and you did your best to fit in.
You lived in the Eldeen Reaches as part of a small Khoravar community, trying to be a bridge between the human farmers in the east and the druids and wilder folk in the west.
Your small Khoravar community has only survived in the slums of Sharn through the close, family-like support you show each other.
You're part of a community in Thrane whose devotion to the Silver Flame has led you to extend your unity meals to non-Khoravar.
Your Khoravar community is the crew of a Lhazaar ship.
You're part of a tiny Khoravar community in Karrnath that's fascinated with death and the practices of your Aereni ancestors, transforming your unity meals into grim celebrations of death.
You're part of a tiny community of Khoravar living in an unexpected place, such as Droaam, Darguun, or even the Demon Wastes. Your people strive to find common ground with the native population.
You are associated with House Lyrandar or House Medani, but you're more interested in the role the house plays in supporting Khoravar communities than in the work of its guilds.
You ride with the Valenar, hoping one day to prove that you are worthy of taking on a patron ancestor.
table.name: Khoravar Origin

table.caption: Halfling Quirks
rows: You are constantly amazed by things the people of the Five Nations take for granted.
You pattern your behavior on a species of dinosaur.
You are extremely curious, and you're always searching for new experiences.
You love to boast, and you're always telling exaggerated stories of your amazing adventures.
You wear a mask that you believe holds the spirit of your former dinosaur mount. You like to talk to it.
You don't understand the concept of "facts." To you, everything is a story, and truth is in how you tell it.
You are annoyed by buildings and tools designed without consideration for small people.
You seek vengeance for a wrong done to your people.
You never forget an insult or injury.
You ascribe everything to the work of spirits.
table.name: Talenta Halflings; Halfling Quirks

table.caption: Human Origins
rows: An impoverished wizard from Aundair, striving to prove you're as intelligent as any other Aundairian
A streetwise rogue from Breland who wants nothing more than to escape the bustle of Sharn forever
A displaced Cyran fighter who was engaged in war outside Cyre at the time of the Mourning and is now stranded with no home
A barbarian from the Demon Wastes who repented from a life of cruelty and hopes to atone for past evils
A kindly druid from the Eldeen Reaches who wants to learn about the flora and fauna of the rest of Khorvaire and beyond
A cleric from Karrnath who aspires to learn the arts of necromancy—for the noblest aims, of course
A piratical bard from the Lhazaar Principalities who loves sea shanties but also wants to immortalize the deeds of great heroes in song
A ranger trained to hunt the jungles of Q'barra who harbors a grudge against dragons
A warlock from the Shadow Marches, teetering on the edge of sanity while contemplating the daelkyr
A Thrane paladin of the Silver Flame who's looking for something to prove the truth underpinning belief
table.name: Humans; Human Origins

table.caption: Leaving the Shadow Marches
rows: You're associated with the Gatekeepers, and you're on a quest to combat a daelkyr-related threat beyond the bounds of the Shadow Marches.
House Tharashk recruited you from the Marches to serve as a mercenary in the Last War.
You're a simple hunter, but you've decided to seek your fortune or a real challenge in the world beyond the Marches.
Your village was destroyed by monsters from Droaam, so you're looking for a new place in the world.

As a cultist of the Dragon Below, you believe that slaying powerful foes is the only way to earn your passage to the paradise that lies deep within the hollow world. You've ventured beyond the Marches in search of worthy enemies.
Your clan works with House Tharashk, and you've been recruited as a bounty hunter or investigator even though you're not a member of the house.
The leader of your clan committed a great wrong against another clan, which has now sworn to exterminate every last member of your clan. What better time to see the world?
Your work as an investigator has set you upon a trail of mysteries that leads far beyond the Marches.
table.name: Orcs of the Shadow Marches; Leaving the Shadow Marches

table.caption: Dragonmark Quirks
rows: Your dragonmark is unusually small or faint.
Your dragonmark appears somewhere else on your body whenever you finish a long rest.
Your dragonmark emits dim light in a 5-foot radius for 10 minutes whenever you use it.
Your dragonmark tingles and changes color for a moment when you're within 10 feet of someone with the same mark.
When you use your dragonmark, it animates and adopts the appearance of your dragonmarked house's emblem for 1 minute.
Your dragonmark is an unusual color.
Your dragonmark changes size whenever you use it.
table.name: Dragonmark Appearance; Dragonmark Quirks

table.caption: Guild Contacts
rows: The charismatic leader of the guild, who doesn't actually do very much except inspire and encourage members
A retired adventurer who works hard to connect member groups with employment opportunities that match their skills
A petty rival who continually tries to claim jobs, bounties, and rewards before you can
A bitter enemy who nurtures a grudge over some past wrong (real or imagined) and does everything possible to undermine you
A naive adventurer who admires you and tries to emulate you in every way
A hardened adventurer who thinks a moral compass is akin to a pair of manacles
An injured retired adventurer who can't quite let go of the adventuring life and experiences it vicariously by spending time in the guildhall
A grouchy employee who keeps the guildhall clean and cares for its guests while quietly complaining about how adventurers should "grow up," get a "real job," and contribute to society
A kindly mentor who loves to tell stories of past exploits in front of the guildhall fireplace
A sad, older adventurer who tells cautionary tales in the vain hope that younger members avoid making the same mistakes
table.name: Adventurers' Guild Contacts; Guild Contacts

table.caption: Guild Adventures
rows: {@b Crime}. You have to break the law to administer justice or thwart a criminal act (see "{@book Crime Syndicate|ERLW|4|Crime Syndicate}").
{@b Dragonmarked Affairs}. The job involves some dragonmarked house concern (see "{@book Dragonmarked House|ERLW|4|Dragonmarked House}").
{@b Espionage}. Someone requires some spying or sabotage (see "{@book Espionage Agency|ERLW|4|Espionage Agency}").
{@b Statecraft}. You're involved in national or international affairs (see "{@book Head of State|ERLW|4|Head of State}").
{@b Cryptic Mystery}. The job is linked to the concerns of immortals (see "{@book Immortal Being|ERLW|4|Immortal Being}").
{@b Investigation}. An assignment involves finding something or solving a mystery (see "{@book Inquisitive Agency|ERLW|4|Inquisitive Agency}").
{@b Military Action}. Your party is invited to serve as a military unit (see "{@book Military Force|ERLW|4|Military Force}").
{@b Gathering News}. You're called on to act as freelance reporters (see "{@book Newspaper|ERLW|4|Newspaper}").
{@b Religious Work}. The job involves the work of faith (see "{@book Religious Order|ERLW|4|Religious Order}").
{@b Field Research}. The job involves research or relic-hunting (see "{@book University|ERLW|4|University}").
table.name: Guild Adventures

table.caption: Syndicate Crimes
rows: {@b Acquisitions and Retrieval}. Your job is to acquire assets for the syndicate. You might steal important documents or clear out a location for use as a hideout.
{@b Heists}. You plan and execute elaborate robberies that require the skills of everyone on your team.
{@b Gang Warfare}. Your primary job is to ensure that no other crime syndicate (such as Daask or House Tarkanan) gains a significant foothold in your territory.
{@b Internal Affairs}. Your task is to keep all the corrupt, headstrong, and avaricious members of your syndicate in line with the goals and rules of the group.
{@b Assassination}. Your work involves killing prominent people—the sort who have numerous bodyguards and elaborate security systems to circumvent.

{@b Topple the Powerful}. Your syndicate might be criminal and your methods illegal, but your goals are righteous. You help people who are powerless to defend themselves against exploitation by the rich and powerful.
table.name: Types of Crime; Syndicate Crimes

table.caption: Group Infamy
rows: {@b Tattoos}. Each member of your group has a distinct tattoo that inspires fear in others. When possible, you use the symbol as a calling card to mark your work.
{@b Outfit}. Whether it is a leather duster with a group symbol or a distinctive handkerchief tucked in your pocket, your gang has a signature accessory.
{@b Infamy}. Your group is linked to an infamous crime, one that remains the talk of the town.

{@b Idols}. A certain type of person finds criminals alluring, and your band has acquired a group of such hangers-on. They're not criminals themselves, just outsiders who admire you for your brutality, cunning, or flair.

{@b Legitimate}. The Boromar Clan has a legitimate front, though everyone knows the truth behind it. You're part of that facade of legitimacy, but you have a reputation for getting away with (literal) murder.
{@b Legends}. You have an air of mystery, and people whisper that you command strange powers. True or not, this reputation keeps people out of your way.
table.name: Group Infamy

table.caption: Group Rivals
rows: {@b The Law}. Someone in the Sharn Watch has vowed to put you in prison or die trying.
{@b Gang War}. Some members of a rival syndicate (such as Daask, House Tarkanan, or the Tyrants) hate you, probably for good reason.
{@b The Press}. Your group's adventures make for great headlines. Your every move is reported in the broadsheets and your steps are dogged by journalists.
{@b Infighting}. Another group within the Boromar Clan is jealous of your success or angry about a past wrong. They do everything they can to undercut you.
{@b Vigilante}. A citizen you wronged has sworn vengeance. Around any corner, you might find yourself facing a vigilante or a posse of angry citizens out for your blood.
{@b The Bosses}. The halfling family in control of the syndicate has its eye on you, taking pains to keep you in line and make sure you stay loyal.
table.name: Rival Outfit; Group Rivals

table.caption: Syndicate Contact
rows: A surrogate parent who views you as challenging but beloved children
A no-nonsense boss who treats the syndicate's work as just another business
A hardened criminal with no mercy, no patience, and no moral compass
A former urchin, now fabulously wealthy, who wants to see everyone in the syndicate find the same success
The boss at a gambling den or similar house of vice who enjoys the business just a little too much
A kind-hearted crook who's grateful to finally be able to delegate the dirty work on the streets to you
A miserable cynic who only cares about how much money you bring in to the syndicate
A former law enforcement officer who is full of cheerful tips for avoiding the law
table.name: Crime Syndicate Contacts; Syndicate Contact

table.caption: General House Missions
rows: Establish a safe location for a house enclave in a hostile environment.
Find the wreckage of a crashed vehicle (airship, lightning rail car, sailing ship, or other) carrying house property.
Retrieve assets from a house enclave in the Mournland.
Protect a leader of your house from an anticipated assassination attempt.
Enforce your house's territory by preventing a rival from stealing its business.
Find a trove of dragonshards for your patron house to use.
Recruit a renowned sage to join the house's team of researchers.
Persuade a hostile tribe to agree to a trade agreement with your patron house.
table.name: General House Missions

table.caption: House Missions
rows: Escort a valuable shipment of goods
Advance the cause of one branch of the family at the expense of the other two
Act as bodyguards for a prominent or wealthy person
Serve as mercenaries in a lingering border conflict
Enforce the law across national borders as Sentinel Marshals
Defend a Golden Dragon Inn that is under attack
Provide healing for a caravan or military unit on a dangerous mission
Seek out the source of a mysterious new illness
Find a cure for an exotic curse afflicting a wealthy patient
Safeguard something valuable until it is locked in a vault
Recover something stolen from your house
Find an abandoned vault in the Mournland
Hunt down pirates in the Lhazaar Sea
Salvage a prototype airship lost in the Mournland
Accompany a new airship on its first voyage
Protect a powerful figure from kidnapping or assassination
Track down the source of rumors pointing to an imminent threat
Find the villain behind a series of apparently unrelated crimes
Carry a sensitive message to its destination
Retrieve an important package stolen from another courier
Investigate a problem on a lightning rail line
Sneak into a secret area to serve as the target of a scrying spell
Steal plans for a powerful new weapon
Assure that two parties keep to the terms of their agreement
Break a code used during the Last War
Find the bandits who have been preying on house prospectors
Capture wild animals and tame them
Prevent magebred specimens from upsetting a delicate ecosystem
Handle the animals drawing a massive caravan across the continent
table.name: House Missions

table.caption: Group Status
rows: {@b Favored}. You have access to the leadership of the house, owing to your record of faithful service.
{@b Reliable}. You are reliable contributors to the house, and can count on it for help in difficult situations.
{@b Oddballs}. You don't quite fit in, and tend to draw strange assignments or those that other operatives pass up.
{@b Outcast}. You have made some mistakes in the recent past, and your status in the house is tenuous at best.
table.name: House Status; Group Status

table.caption: House Contacts
rows: A lesser guild functionary who is cowed by your group (especially if it includes a dragonmarked character) and apologetic about giving you assignments
The stern and demanding parent of one (or more) of the characters in your group
The lovingly indulgent parent of a character in your group
The smugly superior dragonmarked sibling of an unmarked member of the family in your group
The money-minded business manager of a guild within your patron house
A retired adventurer within the family who would rather join you on your adventures than assign them to you
The proud leader of a regional branch of the dragonmarked family
The patriarch or matriarch of the patron house
table.name: Dragonmarked House Contacts; House Contacts

table.caption: Espionage Missions
rows: {@b Information Gathering}. If information is out there, you can find it and hand it over to your patron.
{@b Counterintelligence}. Your work focuses on finding, opposing, and eliminating enemy intelligence agents.
{@b Misinformation}. You are experts at creating false stories and bogus information to foil enemy spies.
{@b Covert Elimination}. When you disappear someone you leave behind no evidence.
{@b Disruption}. You excel at infiltration and wreaking havoc via blackmail, misinformation, and subversion.
{@b Sabotage}. You slip into places, lay the seeds for their destruction, and escape without detection.
table.name: Types of Espionage; Espionage Missions

table.caption: Secrets
rows: {@b Blackmail Material}. You have evidence of a career-ending secret concerning an important figure.
{@b Hidden Agenda}. You are party to a conspiracy that seeks to influence events to better suit your desires.
{@b Careful Balance}. You have damning information on your patron agency, but it has carefully collected equally damaging secrets on all of you.
{@b Conspiracy}. A local organization, such as a guild, government, or dragonmarked house, is engaged in dirty deeds, and you have inside information on them.
{@b Deep Cover}. You know the secret identity of a seemingly innocent but powerful person who would rather remain anonymous.

{@b Empty Threats}. Rumors say you collect damaging secrets on anyone, and people tread carefully around you as a result. The truth is that your reputation is overblown, so you have your own secret to keep safe.
table.name: Secrets

table.caption: Memorable Mission
rows: {@b Betrayal}. A former associate turned against you. You escaped, and want revenge.
{@b Left in the Cold.} Things went wrong, and you had to make the terrible decision to abandon an ally. They might be dead, or they might be looking for revenge.

{@b The Perfect Operation}. Your actions made headlines across Khorvaire, shaping history for the next decade. Nobody knows you were involved, and sometimes you wish you could have a little credit for your work.

{@b The Standoff}. You met your match during a tense operation. Neither side got everything they wanted. You hate to admit it, but the team you went up against proved your match. Maybe you'll cross paths again.
table.name: Memorable Mission

table.caption: Agency Contacts
rows: A condescending career desk agent who views you as expendable tools
A bitter former field agent, now confined to a field office, who envies your work
A kindly bureau chief who views you as a truly special team with invaluable skills
A crotchety middle-manager on the cusp of retirement who constantly bemoans the state of today's agents compared to those in the "good old days"
A hotheaded former soldier who would prefer a return to open warfare instead of this so-called "Shadow War"
A battle-scarred field agent who would do almost anything to prevent a return to the horrors of the Last War
A bored but effective manager who refuses to be impressed by anything you do or shocked by anything that happens to you
A mysterious voice on the other end of a {@item speaking stone|ERLW}
table.name: Espionage Agency Contacts; Agency Contacts

table.caption: Cyran Affairs
rows: Convince nations to recognize Oargev as a sovereign
Work diplomatically to secure land for a Cyran nation
Track down agents and infiltrators from other nations who are acting against New Cyre's interests
Venture into the Mournland to salvage Cyran treasures
Aid Cyran refugees in Breland and elsewhere
Make incriminating or embarrassing evidence about the prince quietly disappear
table.name: National Affairs; Cyran Affairs

table.caption: State Status
rows: {@b Official}. You hold an official position and are recognized as attached to your patron. You can expect the head of state's support, but you must also ensure your actions avoid staining your patron's reputation.
{@b Shadow}. You can expect no official, public recognition of your work, but the head of state you work for does acknowledge you in private and provide help.

{@b Double}. Your allegiance lies with an official or government other than the one you overtly serve. You may receive support from the head of state you openly answer follow, as well as the official you secretly report to, but must remain on constant guard against having your true loyalties revealed.
table.name: Official Status; State Status

table.caption: State Contacts
rows: A disapproving courtier who finds your extrajudicial work highly distasteful
A fawning sycophant who figures you are the best path to the head of state's good graces
A wide-eyed bureaucrat who dreams of living a life as exciting and dangerous as yours
A scheming relative of the head of state who sees you as a path toward seizing power
A bored chancellor who is constantly irritated at the amount of money you spend
A grumpy ex-adventurer who was "promoted" from doing your job to supervising you
A worried parental figure who is sure that every mission will be your last
The ghost of the previous head of state
table.name: Head of State Contacts; State Contacts

table.caption: Heads of State
rows: As representatives of the Sibling Kings of Aerenal, secure trade pacts with the nations of Khorvaire.
As agents of Queen Aurala, help her build Aundair's strength in preparation for the next war, without alerting other nations to her ambitions.
Assist the Brelish crown in dealing with matters beyond the capabilities of local law enforcement.
As emissaries of Darguun's Lhesh Haruuc, work to build respect for Darguun as a nation.
As agents of the Daughters of Sora Kell, keep the powerful Droaamite warlords in line and strengthen support for your fledging nation.
Patrol the forests of the Eldeen Reaches on guard against threats, particularly those coming from the Demon Wastes to the west.
Crack down on the Order of the Emerald Claw's activities in Karrnath.
Strengthen the ties between the Lhazaar princes while ensuring your prince comes out on top.
On behalf of a dwarf clan, search for artifacts in the underground realms below the Mror Holds.
Clear land for a new settlement in Q'barra, driving out the monsters that haunt the jungle location.
Unite several halfling tribes of the Talenta Plains under the banner of a single leader.
Combat forces of corruption within the Church of the Silver Flame, both in Thrane and abroad.
Gain glory for Valenar by leading raids and battling threats from the Mournland.
On behalf of one member of Zilargo's Triumvirate, collect information that could be used as leverage against the other two.
table.name: Other Heads of State; Heads of State

table.caption: Immortal Missions
rows: While in the tower of Mordain the Fleshweaver, spill blood on the stairs between the third and fourth floors.
As you pursue a Cult of the Dragon Below into the caverns of Khyber, retrieve one (and only one) of a specific variety of mushroom from a cave where twelve crystals glow.
Ensure that the villain you are pursuing dies by falling from a great height, not by any other means.
Remove the obstacles that prevent a retired adventurer from marrying the nobleman she loves, so that their child can grow up to carry out another part of your patron's plan.
