Phenax undertakes a plot to transform Erebos into one of the Returned. If he succeeds, the balance of life and death will be shattered.
Phenax vanishes. For a time, it's believe the god has been killed or grew bored and left Theros. In fact, though, Phenax managed to imprison another god and has since taken their place.

Phenax dispatches a powerful agent to find a lost relic called Deception's Edge, a dagger that enables the wielder to warp the minds of mortals. Once in possession of the artifact, the agent embarks on a campaign of assassination and espionage that threatens to lead to all-out war between Akros and Meletis.
table.name: Phenax's Divine Schemes

table.caption: Amphitheater Adventures
rows: Steal an item from an audience member.
Find evidence of a crime hidden backstage.
Defend a theater being run by a criminal cabal from a rival gang's assault.
Take the place of a group of performers on stage to impress an audience member.
Assassinate an audience member during a performance without being seen.
Serve as bodyguards for an audience member.
Find a spy among the audience members and deliver a message to that person.
Steal costumes from the theater to infiltrate a temple in disguise.
Intercept and decipher a coded message meant for someone else.
table.name: Amphitheater Adventures

table.caption: Amphitheater Villains
rows: An actor charms nobles who see him perform into surrendering their fortunes.
The {@creature wraith} of a murdered actress reenacts her death every night, playing the role of the murderer and targeting a new performer in her place.
An untalented dancer ({@creature scout}) poisons those with more skill in order to get ahead.
A {@creature mage} playwright invites political figures to see his satires, then uses magic to make them react dramatically, which encourages more people to see his plays.
A leading lady is also an {@creature assassin} for hire, and she uses a secret room in the theater as her base.
Burglars ({@creature Veteran||veterans}) masquerading as acrobats identify marks during their performances, then rob them afterward.
A murderer ({@creature spy}) who works as a prop maker hides his weapons and victims in among pieces of the set.
A theater-loving {@creature mage} uses a {@creature homunculus} to spy on audience members to gain blackmail material.
table.name: Amphitheater Villains

table.caption: Purphoros's Quests
rows: Clear out a monster-infested mine and help procure precious iron ore for a master smith.
Protect a traveling theater troupe as they perform a new play that glorifies Purphoros and makes another god look foolish.
Retrieve a sacred weapon of Purphoros that has fallen into the hands of minotaurs.
Resist the corrupt authority of a powerful priest of Heliod or a cruel village elder.
Triumph in a contest of strength or crafting to bring glory to Purphoros.
Defeat a champion of another god (most likely Heliod, Kruphix, Phenax, or Mogis).
table.name: Purphoros's Quests

table.caption: Purphoros's Villains
rows: A {@creature cult fanatic} of Purphoros turns to Mogis to enhance his craft, engaging in bloody rituals to produce exquisite cursed weapons.
An aging {@creature veteran} seeks to replace her body with living bronze and enlists a genius {@creature archmage} of Purphoros to aid her. Then several of their test limbs escape.
A rebel ({@creature spy}) plots to set fire to a temple of Heliod and dedicate the blaze to Purphoros, driving the gods toward a conflict he's certain Purphoros will win.
A {@creature gladiator} of Purphoros partakes of the fumes at Mount Velus then goes on what seems to be a rampage that contributes to a mysterious design.
A {@creature priest} of Purphoros condemns the party for treating their weapons and tools poorly, insisting they discard them until the heroes prove their worthiness.
A group of {@creature Oread|MOT|oreads} (see {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Oread}) seeks inspiration in flames. The oreads leave Purphoros's forge and conduct thorough studies of everything they burn.
table.name: Purphoros's Villains

table.caption: Purphoros's Monsters
footnotes: * See {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Classic Monsters} for details about these creatures in Theros.
table.name: Purphoros's Monsters

table.caption: Purphoros's Divine Schemes
rows: Enraged at Heliod's latest insult, Purphoros causes Mount Velus to erupt. The volcano's rage doesn't cease, though, threatening the region.
Insulted that the other gods don't appreciate his creations, Purphoros breaks the Nyx-infused chains that bind the ancient red dragon Thraxes, allowing it to go on a far-ranging rampage.

Gripped by sudden inspiration, Purphoros begins building a massive Nyx-bronze bridge that will link Mount Velus in the mortal world with Nyx itself. Every god opposes him in this effort. Can the construction effort be sabotaged without bringing the bridge tumbling down on the mortal world?

Purphoros's double, Petros, reveals an army of metal Nyxborn creatures and unleashes them against temples and settlements dedicated to other gods. The gods blame Purphoros for the attack, but he is too proud, and too fond of Petros, to stop the attacks.
table.name: Purphoros's Divine Schemes

table.caption: Volcano Temple Adventures
rows: Acquire an item that wasn't up to Purphoros's standards before it's cast into the lava.
Defend the temple from fiery zombies emerging from tunnels connecting to a collapsed temple.
Steal a phoenix egg from the temple.
Become an apprentice to one of the priests and craft an item in the temple.
Explore a ruined temple after an eruption to make sure it is safe for others to enter.
Stop the temple priests from destroying well-crafted but substandard armor and weapons that are needed by a nearby settlement.
The volcano is erupting! Prevent it, or save the most fanatical priests who refuse to leave their forges.
Negotiate with fire giants who want to use the temple's forges.
Destroy a near-indestructible item in the volcano's forges.
Rescue an artisan lost in the temple's twisting halls.
table.name: Volcano Temple Adventures

table.caption: Volcano Temple Villains
rows: An {@creature adult red dragon} tries to make its nest inside the temple, attacking the artisans and priests within.

A {@creature priest} of Mogis infiltrates the volcano and mars its ornate halls, hoping to draw Purphoros's ire and thus cause the volcano to erupt at an unexpected time, killing everyone in the temple.
A obsessed {@creature cult fanatic} is never satisfied with her apprentices' creations and works them to death.
A unit of defeated and desperate {@b hoplites} (see {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Hoplites}) raid the temple, steal magical weapons, and prepare to avenge their fallen companions.
An apprentice artisan summons {@creature Fire Elemental||fire elementals} that he can't control to murder his cruel master.
An {@creature iron golem} forged in the temple breaks free of its maker's control and goes on a killing spree.
table.name: Volcano Temple Villains

table.caption: Thassa's Quests
rows: Help a village of Thassa's faithful evacuate to the hills before Thassa sends a great wave to punish the village's willful coastal neighbors.
Phenax has learned the location of a sunken treasure in a flooded cave. Retrieve the treasure before his fortune-hunters can steal it from Thassa.

Smuggle a cargo of offerings for Thassa past harbor inspectors at Meletis, skirting new laws put into place at the behest of Heliod's priesthood that ban the import of items intended for sacrifice to other gods.
Find a magically stolen vessel sequestered high in the mountains and return it to the ocean.
Capture a great beast of the land and bring it to the shore as an offering for a kraken.
Humiliate a champion of another god (most likely Ephara, Karametra, Pharika, Iroas, or Mogis).
table.name: Thassa's Quests

table.caption: Thassa's Villains
rows: A {@creature triton master of waves|MOT} (see {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Triton}) demands ever greater sacrifices to Thassa from merchants moving along a crucial trade route, threatening to sink ships that don't comply.
A former {@creature priest} of Thassa kidnaps indigents and plans to drown them as offerings to regain her favor.
A {@creature druid} of Thassa, after being mistreated by a coastal community, uses magic to lure a plague of {@creature Giant Crab||giant crabs} out of the depths to take revenge.
A {@creature water elemental} is trapped in a village well and has changed the drinking water to saltwater. It needs help returning to the sea.
Sirens (see the harpies entry in {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Harpies}) favored by Thassa take up residence in a lighthouse, preventing its use.

A ship carrying a massive pearl sacred to Thassa has been sunk. Thassa's {@creature Cultist||cultists} want the pearl back, but anyone trying to retrieve it find that the god's triton followers have claimed it.
table.name: Thassa's Villains

table.caption: Thassa's Monsters
footnotes: * See {@book chapter 6|MOT|6} for details about these creatures in Theros.
table.name: Thassa's Monsters

table.caption: Thassa's Divine Schemes
rows: After a kraken is sighted near an inhabited island, a fleet prepares to set sail from Meletis to face it. In retribution, Thassa pulls the ocean back from the entire coastline, stranding not only the fleet, but the fishing boats and merchant vessels that keep the polis fed and supplied. Thassa's oracles announce that "the forest of masts must be felled" before the waters will return, but Meletis refuses to give up its navy. How can Thassa be appeased?
During a divine conflict, one of the gods' weapons tumbles into the sea. Thassa refuses to return the godly weapon, claiming it as her own, much to the owner's ire.

Thassa turns a ship full of another god's champions into dolphins as punishment for setting foot on one of her holy isles. Can she be persuaded to change them back? How will the champions' patrons respond if she refuses?
When multiple gods turn against her in a dispute, Thassa is enraged. She releases the locks binding every kraken in the sea, along with that of an ancient and mysterious kraken brood mother.
table.name: Thassa's Divine Schemes

table.caption: Coastal Temple Adventures
rows: Save land-dwelling worshipers who became trapped inside the temple during a flood.
Steal an offering before it washes away.
Confront pirates worshiping at the temple.
Defend the temple from kraken-worshiping cultists.
Kill or drive off a {@creature hydra} that has claimed the temple as its home.
Help a {@creature killer whale} beached in the temple.
Kidnap a worshiper without making a scene.
Steal a magic {@creature quipper} from a sacred tide pool.
Spy on a conversation between two worshipers.
Negotiate with a {@b blue dragon} that wants to claim the temple as its lair.
Escape the temple as it floods.
table.name: Coastal Temple Adventures

table.caption: Coastal Temple Villains
rows: A {@creature kraken} threatens to destroy the temple if worshipers don't pay tribute to the creature.
A {@creature Naiad|MOT} (see {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Naiad}) hides inside the temple and murders fishers who worship here for their crimes against the sea.
A group of sirens (see the {@creature Harpy||harpies} entry in {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Harpies}) take over the temple and lure new victims inside to drown themselves during high tide.
A {@creature priest} of Thassa falsely convinces elderly worshipers that giving more wealth to the temple increases the length of time they live.
A {@creature giant octopus} under the effects of the {@spell awaken} spell hunts in the temple at high tide.
A rageful {@creature triton master of waves|MOT} (see {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Triton Master of Waves}) believes everyone in a temple is secretly serving a kraken and begins murdering them.
table.name: Coastal Temple Villains

table.caption: Adventures at Sea
rows: Slay a monster or pirates terrorizing ships at sea.
Follow an omen that leads out to sea.
Seek an artifact hidden underwater or on an island.
Find your way home after getting lost.
Find a lost temple of a god.
Relocate settlers trying to colonize an inhabited isle.
Discover a safe route through deadly waters.
Retrace the path of a hero lost at sea.
Find a whirlpool that is a passage to the Underworld.
Sail from the edge of the world into Nyx.
table.name: Embarking on Adventure; Adventures at Sea

table.caption: Island Environments
rows: Frozen. The island is magically frozen or is a floating iceberg. Perhaps something lies locked within.
Sargassum. The island is a dense layer of seaweed that has developed its own ecosystem of strange beasts and trapped sailors.
Living. The island is actually a gigantic slumbering creature—potentially unbeknown to its residents.
Mirage. Magical phenomena surround a mundane island with tempting or treacherous illusions.
Nyx Shard. The island is a manifestation of Nyx, a recreation of a land from the distant past or completely from fiction.
Idyllic. The island has beautiful weather and abundant fruit—so much so that some might consider never leaving.
Lost Ruin. The island is all that survived a calamity that destroyed a legendary city.
Gateway. The island is inherently magical, perhaps being an intrusion from a bizarre demiplane or the dream of a sleeping demigod.
Promised Land. The island is a gift from a god to a favored individual or population, specially tailored to suit their whims.
Divine Refuge. A god created this island to be a personal getaway, making it a reflection of the world as it would appear if they were in complete control.
table.name: Island Environments

table.caption: Island Inhabitants
rows: The Last. Creatures that think they're the last of their kind—perhaps Returned, leonin, or humans—make their home on the island.
First Contact. A prosperous civilization, unconnected to the great poleis, thrives on the island.
Strangers. A species not usually connected to Theros dwells here—such as thri-kreen, yuan-ti, or another creature from the {@book Monster Manual|MM}.
Rivals. Two settlements have turned the island into a war zone.
Prisoner. A powerful monster or dangerous figure from legend is imprisoned on this island.
Tyrant. A powerful individual built a fortress on the island, and all other residents revere them.
Fanatics. The island's residents know only one god and don't appreciate visits from heretics.
The Dead. A settlement of the Returned is located near an obscure passage to the Underworld.
Memories. Everyone on the island is Nyxborn, being the reincarnation of a lost people.
Oracle. An oracle with a reputation for accurate knowledge and prediction lives on the island.
table.name: Island Inhabitants

table.caption: Underwater Adventures
rows: Seek aid or advice from the eldest member of an aquatic species—such as the first dolphin.
Recover the treasure of a hero long ago devoured by a sea beast.
Carry a coastal city's gifts and diplomatic messages to an underwater community.
Calm a kraken attempting to break out of its sea lock (see {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Kraken}).
Make a sacrifice at a triton temple devoted to Thassa or another god.
Transform into a sea creature and infiltrate an undersea community.
Convince a hero who's fallen in love with a sea dweller to return home.
Raise a sunken city back above the waves while avoiding whatever now makes the place its home.
Seek information from an oracle who lives on a sunken island inside a giant bubble.
Seal a hole in the sea that's allowing denizens of the Underworld ward of Nerono to escape.
Return a juvenile sea monster caught in a fisher's net to its home.
Protect a priest of Thassa intent on journeying to the bottom of the sea.
table.name: Underwater Adventures

table.caption: Underworld Adventures
rows: In Phylias, find and bargain for information with your least favorite dead acquaintance or family member.
Smuggle the puppy of an {@creature Underworld cerberus|MOT} (see {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Underworld Cerberus}) into the mortal world.
Find and free a lost hero from the Labyrinth of Memories on Nerono.
Free a legendary lost ship and the souls aboard from the endless Nerono whirlpool they're trapped within.
Meet with your family's most legendary member in Ilysia and prove yourself worthy of their name.
Steal a legendary, long-shattered treasure from its resting place in Ilysia's Citadel of Destiny.
Seek out a long-dead foe and learn how they're keeping you from being magically resurrected.
Discover a secret from an infamous member of your family who became a {@creature typhon|MOT} (see {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Typhon}).
Save a god's favored worshiper from a cruel punishment in the Underworld—even though they've been dead for hundreds of years.
Sever one of the massive chains of Tizerus, releasing the ancient being it binds.
Lead an immortal anvilwrought to Erebos's palace and convince the god to let the construct die.
Discover why Erebos is no longer allowing certain individuals to die.
Coerce a {@creature night hag} into granting a morbid prophecy by stealing its eye.
Learn a secret way to escape the Underworld from one of the titans.
Find the lost secret of a long-dead warlord that now rests with the villain's misera.
Discover from a {@creature woe strider|MOT} (see {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Woe Strider}) how to escape the bonds of destiny.
Defeat a host of legendary villains in Agonas's Stadium of Dishonor.
Prevent one of your ancestors from transforming into an {@creature eater of hope|MOT} (see {@book chapter 6|MOT|6|Eater of Hope}).
Travel to Erebos's palace and recover a secret from one who failed to bargain for their release.
Seek out Klothys's domain and learn from her oracles how you're destined to escape the Underworld.
table.name: Underworld Adventures

table.caption: Remarkable Origins
rows: The item bears the name or emblem of a lost troop of Akroan stratians (described in {@book chapter 3|MOT|3|Stratians}).
The item is etched with a name or prayer written in Celestial (the language of the gods).
The item looks like it's been at the bottom of the sea for a hundred years but functions perfectly.
The item is wrapped in handwritten scrolls, suggesting it was once possessed by a founder of one of Meletis's philosophical schools (described in {@book chapter 3|MOT|3|Meletis}).
The item bears a design or sculpted feature suggestive of a Returned mask.
A knotted cover or grip depicts colorful birds or stylized herd animals from the plains of Oreskos.

The item is at least partially made from the heartwood of a Setessan caryatid (described in {@book chapter 3|MOT|3|Caryatid Groves}). The wood regularly sprouts fresh leaves, or its whorls suggest humanoid features.
The item rests among the remains of its former owner, who thanks (or curses) those who take it.
The item is at least partially made of iron.
Whoever first touches the item receives an omen from the god who watches over it (see {@book chapter 4|MOT|4|Omens} for details on omens).
The item lies in a crater, as if it fell from the heavens.
The item glimmers with the stars of Nyx and is a perfect facsimile of an item used by a legendary hero.
table.name: Gifts of the Gods; Remarkable Origins

table.caption: Weapons of the Gods Adventures
rows: Steal a god's weapon to lay low one of that god's servants—a creature that can only be harmed by its creator's wrath.
Recover a god's weapon that has been stolen by another god's champion in an attempt to frame the weapon's owner for cruel acts.
Wrest back a god's weapon from a divine champion who needed it but refuses to return it.
Destroy a god's weapon and channel the energy released to create a new magic item or work a miracle.
Reforge a god's weapon after an incredible feat caused it to shatter.

A god's weapon has gained sentience (see "{@book Sentient Magic Items|DMG|-1}" in chapter 7 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}). Determine whether to use it, return it to its creator, or help it grow into its own being.
table.name: Artifacts; Weapons of the Gods Adventures

table.caption: Nyxborn Monster Origin
rows: A god created the creature to serve as an emissary.
The creature formed as the side effect of some other divine action.
The creature escaped from the Underworld.
The creature took shape from the tales told about it.
A god made the creature to serve as a pet or mount.
The creature took shape from dreams or nightmares.
table.name: Nyxborn Creatures; Nyxborn Monster Origin

table.caption: Nyxborn Traits
rows: {@b Magic Resistance}. The creature's Nyxborn nature gives it advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.
{@b Light Sensitivity}. A creature of the night sky, the Nyxborn has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, while it is in bright light.
{@b Immutable Form}. The Nyxborn creature is the philosophical ideal of its kind. It is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.
{@b Magic Weapons}. The Nyxborn creature's weapon attacks are magical.
{@b Nyx Step}. The Nyxborn can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. It takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.
{@b Starlight Form}. The Nyxborn glows with the soft light of the night sky, shedding dim light in a 15-foot radius.
table.name: Nyxborn Statistics; Nyxborn Traits

table.caption: Damage by Level and Severity
table.name: Screen; Damage by Level and Severity

table.caption: Improvising Damage
rows: Burned by coals, hit by a falling bookcase, pricked by a poison needle
Being struck by lightning, stumbling into a fire pit
Hit by falling rubble in a collapsing tunnel, stumbling into a vat of acid
Crushed by compacting walls, hit by whirling steel blades, wading through a lava stream
Being submerged in lava, being hit by a crashing flying fortress
Tumbling into a vortex of fire on the Elemental Plane of Fire, being crushed in the jaws of a godlike creature or a moon-sized monster
table.name: Screen; Improvising Damage

rows: Disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws
table.name: Exhaustion

rows: The area is dangerously worn and prone to collapse. Any impacts or damage to the structure, including from spells and other areas of effect, have a 50 percent chance of causing a collapse (see the {@table Improvising Damage|DMG} table).
Areas within the dungeon section are choked with rubble and have a {@chance 50} chance of being {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. {@quickref Cover||3||Half cover} and hiding places are plentiful.
One dungeon {@5etools hazard|trapshazards.html} such as {@hazard brown mold}, {@hazard yellow mold}, or {@hazard green slime} is abundant.
Most of the dungeon is deserted and quiet as a tomb. Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks have disadvantage because any sounds stand out as unusual.
Ability checks made to break down doors, open locks, or similar breaking and entering activities have disadvantage.
The dungeon is heavily populated. Any loud noises or other attention-drawing phenomena require a check for Dungeon Encounters (see below).
table.name: State of Ruin

rows: A lone, powerful creature appears! You choose the creature, selecting one with a challenge rating that is 1–3 higher than the level of the player characters. The creature lives in the dungeon or is passing through, and it is hostile toward the group only if they provoke it.

Hostile creatures prowl nearby! You choose the creatures, selecting five with a challenge rating equal to the level of the player characters. These creatures are either monsters native to the dungeon or hostile explorers.
A patch of {@hazard brown mold}, {@hazard green slime}, or {@hazard yellow mold} lies nearby.

A group of friendly explorers crosses the player characters' path. The explorers have {@dice 2d4} goods for sale that cost 1 gp or less, which you can select from the {@table Adventuring Gear|PHB} table in the Player's Handbook.
table.name: Dungeon Encounters

table.caption: Travel Pace
rows: -5 penalty to passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) scores
table.name: Screen; Travel Pace

table.caption: Cover
rows: +2 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws against attacks and effects that originate on the opposite side of the cover
+5 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws against attacks and effects that originate on the opposite side of the cover
Can't be targeted directly by an attack or a spell
table.name: Screen; Cover

table.caption: Obscured Areas
rows: Creatures have disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.
Dim light, patchy fog, moderate foliage
Vision is blocked; creatures are effectively {@condition blinded}.
table.name: Screen; Obscured Areas

table.caption: Tracking DCs
rows: Each day since the creature passed
Creature left a trail such as blood
table.name: Screen; Tracking DCs

table.caption: Foraging DCs
rows: Very little, if any, food and water sources
table.name: Screen; Foraging DCs

table.caption: Wilderness Encounter
rows: A lone, powerful creature appears! The DM chooses the creature, selecting one with a challenge rating that is 1-3 higher than the group's level. The creature lives in the area or is passing through, and it is hostile toward the group only if they provoke it.

Hostile creatures prowl nearby! The DM chooses the creatures, selecting five with a challenge rating equal to the group's level. These creatures are either monsters native to the area or hostile travelers
A group of friendly travelers crosses the group's path. The travelers have {@dice 2d6} goods for sale that cost 1 gp or less on the Adventuring Gear table in the Player's Handbook
The group discovers a monument. Roll on the {@table Wilderness Journeys; Monuments|ScreenWildernessKit|Monuments} table.
The group wanders into a strange place. Roll on the {@table Wilderness Journeys; Weird Locales|ScreenWildernessKit|Weird Locales} table.
table.name: Random Encounter; Wilderness Encounter

table.caption: Monuments
rows: Faces carved into a mountainside or cliff
Giant statues carved out of a mountainside or cliff
intact obelisk etched with a warning, historical lore, dedication, or religious iconography
Intact statue of a person or deity
Ruined or toppled statue of a person or deity
Great stone wall, intact, with tower fortifications spaced at one-mile intervals
Ruined or toppled circle of standing stones
Pillar carved with elemental or fey symbols
table.name: Wilderness Journeys; Monuments

table.caption: Weird Locales
rows: Dead magic zone (similar to an antimagic field)
Wild magic zone (roll on the {@table Wild Magic Surge|PHB} table in the Player's Handbook whenever a spell is cast within the zone)
Crystal cave that mystically answers questions
Ancient tree containing a trapped spirit
Battlefield where lingering fog occasionally assumes humanoid forms
A portal to another plane of existence
Giant crystal shard protruding from the ground
Wrecked ship, even if water is nowhere nearby
River ferry guided by a skeletal captain
Field of {@condition petrified} soldiers or other creatures
Forest of {@condition petrified} or {@creature awakened tree||awakened trees}
Floating earth mote with a tower on it
table.name: Wilderness Journeys; Weird Locales

table.caption: Wilderness Chase Complications
rows: Your path takes you through a rough patch of brush. Make a DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check (your choice) to get past the brush. On failed check, the brush counts as 5feet of {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

Uneven ground threatens to slow your progress. Make a DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check to navigate the area. On failed check, the ground counts as 10 feet of {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.
You run through a {@creature swarm of insects} (see the Monster Manual For game statistics). The swarm makes an opportunity attack against you (+3 to hit; {@damage 4d4} piercing damage on a hit).

A stream, ravine, or rock bed blocks your path. Make a DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check (your choice) to cross the impediment. On a failed check, the impediment counts as 10 feet of {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

Make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. Ona failed save, you are {@condition blinded} by blowing sand,dirt, ash, snow,or pollen until the end of your turn. While {@condition blinded} in this way, your speed is halved.

A sudden drop catches you by surprise. Make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw to navigate the impediment. On failed save, you fall {@dice 1d4 x 5} feet, taking {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage per 10 feet fallen as normal, and land {@condition prone}.

You blunder into a snare. Make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On failed save, you are caught in the snare and {@condition restrained}. As an action, you or someone within 5 feet of you can make a DC 10 Strength check, freeing you on a success. The snare can also be destroyed; it has an AC of 10 and 5 hit points, and it is immune to poison and psychic damage. Complication

You are caught in a stampede of spooked animals. Make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw. Ona failed save, you are knocked about and take {@damage 1d4} bludgeoning damage and {@damage 1d4} piercing damage.

Your path takes you near a patch of razorvine. Make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or use 10 feet of movement (your choice) to avoid the razorvine. On a failed save, you take {@damage 1d10} slashing damage.

One or more creatures in the area chase after you! The DM chooses these pursuers or rolls a {@dice d8} to determine them: (1) 2 {@creature brown bear||brown bears}, (2) {@dice 2d4} {@creature giant toad||giant toads}, (3) {@dice 1d4} {@creature poisonous snake||poisonous snakes}, (4) {@dice 2d4} {@creature wolf||wolves}, (5) 1 {@creature giant boar}, (6) 2 {@creature dire wolf||dire wolves}, (7) {@creature griffon}, or (8) {@dice 1d12} {@creature giant rat||giant rats} (see the {@book Monster Manual|MM} for the creatures' game statistics).
table.name: Playing a Chase; Wilderness Chase Complications

table.caption: Academy Type
rows: {@b Boarding School}. Students and faculty enjoy a familial relationship on a self-contained campus.
{@b Arcane Enclave}. Drawn together by cutting-edge magical scholarship, the enclave's residents are hungry for secrets, reagents, and subjects.
{@b Secret Monastery}. Ageless secrets remain the focus of contemplation and rigorous training at this site.
{@b Elite Institute}. This cutthroat college of science or the arts accepts only the crème de la crème of society and talent.
{@b Vault of Secrets}. This conspiracy strives to keep or eradicate all knowledge of a specific truth.
{@b Museum of Dreams}. Magical communication or shared dreamscapes connect a network of wide-ranging specialists.
table.name: Academy Type

table.caption: Academy Contact
rows: {@b Harried Functionary}. A disinterested secretary conveys written correspondence to you from an exceptionally busy or aloof senior faculty member.
{@b Celebrated Instructor}. Despite their throngs of ambitious assistants, a celebrity researcher considers you their star pupil.
{@b Wizened Fixture}. A fantastically old, believed-to-be-deceased librarian gives you assignments from the circulation desk they never leave.
{@b Infatuated Tourist}. A flirtatious visiting scholar perceives your every report and donated discovery as a personal gift.
{@b Spectral Fragment}. A haunted piece of the academy's collection compels you to complete its secret research.
{@b Distant Observer}. A mysterious sponsor encourages your research from afar to avoid alerting nefarious forces embedded within the academy's bureaucracy.
table.name: Academy Contact

table.caption: Academy Factotum Roles
rows: {@background Acolyte}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Noble}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Sage}, {@background Urchin}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Entertainer}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Sage}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Charlatan}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Hermit}, {@background Sage}
table.name: Academy Factotum Roles

table.caption: Academy Quests
rows: {@b Aberrant Zoology}. You undertake expeditions to document, capture, and explain beings antithetical to the natural order.
{@b Arcanodynamics}. You investigate the ways magic underpins existence, exploring its flows and seeking ways to harness its nexuses.
{@b Forbidden History}. You reveal the lost truths of the world's darkest ages, pursuing the history of purposefully hidden or taboo eras.
{@b Cryptogeography}. You search for proof of a hidden land or that the world isn't structured as commonly assumed.
{@b Restorative Antiquarianism}. You track clues leading to plundered artifacts and then restore them to their rightful owners.
{@b Evolutionary Divinity}. You dare to explore what no mortal was meant to know: the origins of divinity.
table.name: Academy Quests

table.caption: Ancient Being
rows: {@b Elder Dragon}. An ancient dragon seeks knowledge or power. It wishes to gather greater wealth for its hoard, its ambitions expanding in its advancing years.
{@b Lich}. An undead spellcaster of immense power employs your group. Its interests are strangely diverse and seemingly benign. Perhaps it's not as evil as conventional adventuring wisdom suggests?

{@b Bound Fiend}. This fiend is bound to a location, either in its true form or as a possessing spirit. Whether trapped in an unbreakable circle of binding sigils or sealed as a spirit within a gigantic statue, the fiend's influence drives your group.

{@b Guardian Celestial}. An angel or another powerful celestial takes an interest in a specific region of the Material Plane. It cultivates a network of mortal informants and agents to serve its agenda.

{@b The Endless}. This person has lived many lifetimes because they can't die—at least not permanently. No matter the cause of their demise, they return. To all appearances, they are alive and mortal, but they control the amassed resources of an immortal.

{@b Primal Manifestation}. Its existence defies mortal understanding; the being simply is. It could be a primordial force of nature awakened to self-awareness that now inhabits the landscape or an alien intellect that whispers through proxies, omens, and idols.
table.name: Ancient Being

table.caption: Ancient Being Contact
rows: {@b Employer}. An established member of local society acts as the interface between you and the patron and provides the cover of legitimate employment. They could be a bartender, shopkeeper, local official, or noble.
{@b Back-Room Dealers}. An exclusive area in an otherwise-ordinary establishment requires a password or token to gain entry. There you meet and communicate with shadowy agents of your patron.

{@b Magical Message Drop}. Magically recorded messages from your contact or your patron appear in odd places. You know to check a predetermined location, such as a crack in an ancient monolith or a specific grave, for instructions.

{@b Visions}. Your patron doesn't use intermediaries, instead speaking to you in dreams, omens, or visions. The being appears in your mind as you sleep, taking control of your dreams to deliver instructions that become difficult to ignore.

{@b Ephemeral Echo}. Your contact never physically reveals itself to you. Perhaps it is the ghost of a dead person, an entity that appears outside the flow of time, or a projected illusion of a being that never leaves your patron's hidden sanctum.
{@b The Mouthpiece}. The ancient being's voice whispers through the lips of an ordinary person. You patron might posses the body of a stranger or a party member to converse with you.
table.name: Ancient Being Contact

table.caption: Ancient Being Operative Roles
rows: {@background Charlatan}, {@background Entertainer}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Hermit}, {@background Sage}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Entertainer}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Sage}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Hermit}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Soldier}
table.name: Ancient Being Operative Roles

table.caption: Ancient Being Quests
rows: {@b Rescue}. A wayward agent went missing while gathering information or materials. You must discover their fate and recover them and their findings.
{@b Sabotage}. You must destroy an aspect of a rival's organization, either assassinating a key minion or destroying a critical object.
{@b Artifice}. Your specialized skills are instrumental to assembling components for a powerful magic ritual or object.

{@b Treachery}. A high-profile minion of another powerful figure is in a position to betray their master, to the benefit of your patron. You must convince them to defect to your organization or extract them from now-hostile territory.

{@b Culling}. A respected agent of your patron (possibly an ally or a mentor for your group) has been compromised. Perhaps they are defecting to a rival, attempting to seize the ancient being's power. Whatever the case, you must catch them to end their threat.

{@b Astral Heist}. A powerful rival of your patron stores their secrets in a mind vault on the Astral Plane. That means they can't be tricked or coerced into revealing anything, nor can their thoughts be read. You must find the vault and travel through the rival's deadly memories to find the knowledge your patron desires.
table.name: Ancient Being Quests

table.caption: Aristocrat Types
rows: {@b Local Lord}. Convinced that power and prestige lie just around the corner, this minor lordling grasps for every opportunity to climb the ranks.
{@b Merchant Mastermind}. Reputation, wealth, and power are one and the same for the head of a family with world-spanning business holdings.
{@b Nomadic Princeling}. Nothing is more appealing to this princeling than treasure. Their sprawling merchant caravan trails behind their palanquin as far as the eye can see.
{@b Double Dealer}. The leader of a noble family has turned against their nation, secretly opposing their liege for personal gain or ethical reasons.
{@b Ambitious Entrepreneur}. The sole heir of a vast fortune, this entrepreneur seeks allies to expand their wealth in a new business on the international, global, or planar stage.
{@b Future Ruler}. This young noble is destined to rule, but currently their whims are fickle and dangerous.
table.name: Aristocrat Types

table.caption: Aristocrat Contact
rows: {@b Common Contact}. A servant with ambitions toward a title works as a go-between for your patron.
{@b Professional}. A level-headed advisor or manager of your patron's business directs you in keeping their reckless employer safe.
{@b Family Peacemaker}. A naive aristocrat appointed by your patron wants your assistance in keeping the peace between fractious family members, which isn't your patron's priority.
{@b Intimate Connection}. A common-born confidant or lover of your patron guides you in creating circumstances to bolster the noble family's best interests.
{@b Outside Insider}. An outcast noble favored by your patron works with you to uphold their family's interests despite their exile.
{@b Outsider Inside}. A mysterious entity manipulates a noble family's fortunes. Through your patron, it employs you to help guide its chosen family along a centuries-long course.
table.name: Aristocrat Contact

table.caption: Aristocrat Retainer Roles
rows: {@background Acolyte}, {@background Charlatan}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Hermit}, {@background Sage}
{@background Criminal}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Soldier}
{@background Entertainer}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Sailor}, {@background Soldier}, {@background Urchin}
table.name: Aristocrat Retainer Roles

table.caption: Aristocrat Quests
rows: {@b Noble Union}. You work within multiple noble factions to unite rival families.
{@b Business Breakthrough}. You track down and obtain a wonder your patron believes is the key to their financial fortunes.
{@b Sabotage Rival}. You break into the business or estate of an enemy noble family and undermine their political or professional ventures.
{@b Lost Lineage}. You seek evidence of a lost branch of a noble family or proof that individuals don't possess a noble pedigree.
{@b Origin of Nobility}. You reveal the secret reason why certain individuals were elevated to noble status and how they will soon fulfill their purpose.
{@b The New Nobility}. You recreate the remarkable event that granted today's noble families their special standing, enabling the rise of new nobles.
table.name: Aristocrat Quests

table.caption: Syndicate Types
rows: {@b Thieves' Guild}. A disparate convocation of thieves, spies, smugglers, and other scoundrels controls criminal activity in a region of a city.

{@b Assassin Society}. The network's livelihood is death. Members of the society hone their skills as cutthroats, poisoners, body-disposal specialists, and any other profession focused on ending lives. The society is motivated by profit or labors in service to a greater cause.

{@b Magical Arms Dealer}. The syndicate has cornered the market on deadly magical devices. They offer their services and wares for a price and acquire staggering magical might for those who meet their demands.
{@b Pirate Fleet}. This alliance of pirate captains is unified under a ruling captain or admiral and adheres to a strict code of honor. They converge only in response to an outside threat.

{@b Body Snatchers}. The syndicate consists predominantly, if not entirely, of creatures that possess or impersonate other people. They seek to replace influential individuals throughout society with members of their ranks.
{@b Thought Thieves}. These psychic criminals infiltrate their target's minds to steal secrets and disguise their existence.
table.name: Types of Criminal Syndicates; Syndicate Types

table.caption: Syndicate Contact
rows: {@b Personal Mentor}. This longtime member of the syndicate took you under their wing when you were young and became a parental figure.
{@b Clever Urchin}. An innocuous person, perhaps a beggar or menial laborer, knows all the right people and shares their connections with you.

{@b Former Law Enforcement}. Your contact used to be (or maybe still is) a member of local law enforcement. They have sharp insight into the law's workings in your area and a healthy dose of paranoia for that reason.
{@b Bon Vivant}. The boss of a local den of vice—whether gambling, narcotics, or other pleasures—aids you when they're not distracted by their own debauchery.
{@b Traitor}. You know your contact in the syndicate has betrayed it, but they have enough clout and leverage that you don't dare cross them—yet.
{@b Criminal Royalty}. Unknown to most, your contact is a member of local nobility or royalty. Why they maintain relations with the syndicate is a troubling mystery.
table.name: Criminal Syndicate Contact; Syndicate Contact

table.caption: Criminal Syndicate Member Roles
rows: {@background Criminal}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Urchin}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Charlatan}, {@background Criminal}, {@background Entertainer}, {@background Noble}, {@background Urchin}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Charlatan}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Noble}, {@background Soldier}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Criminal}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Sage}
table.name: Criminal Syndicate Member Roles

table.caption: Criminal Syndicate Quests
rows: {@b Acquisition and Retrieval}. You acquire assets for the syndicate. You steal important documents or clear out locations for use as hideouts.
{@b Heists}. You plan and execute elaborate robberies that require the combined skills of your team.
{@b Gang Warfare}. You ensure that no other crime syndicate gains a significant foothold in your territory.
{@b Enforcement}. You keep the corrupt, headstrong, and avaricious members of your syndicate in line with the goals and rules of the organization.
{@b Assassination}. You dispatch prominent people—the sort who have numerous bodyguards and elaborate security systems to circumvent.
{@b Topple the Powerful}. Your syndicate is criminal and your methods illegal, but your goals are righteous. You help people who are powerless against exploitation by the powerful.
table.name: Criminal Syndicate Quests

table.caption: Guild Types
rows: {@b Crafters' Guild}. This conglomerate of artisans pools its resources and influence to ensure a steady exchange of gold for its crafts.
{@b Merchant Consortium}. These entrepreneurs don't create the wares they peddle, instead specializing in linking products to prospective owners. If they don't have it, they find it.

{@b Miracle Makers' Association}. The magically inclined crafters of this guild specialize in imbuing physical goods with magical effects. Rumor has it they can strip the magic from existing enchanted items and might be willing to buy or trade adventurers' spoils.

{@b Moneychangers}. These merchants deal in all forms of currency, acting as bankers, loan agents, and crucial contacts for adventurers and other individuals who deal with large sums of wealth. They exchange coin for gemstones as readily as they find buyers for historical relics and recovered art.
{@b Philosophical Faction}. These like-minded individuals follow specific teachings, spreading word of their expertise through their services and training.
{@b Identity Traders}. These enigmatic dealers buy and sell documents, memories, and the trappings of thoroughly lived lives, selling them to those in need of the ultimate fresh start.
table.name: Guild Types

table.caption: Guild Contact
rows: {@b The Perfectionist}. Your contact is a skilled but obsessive creator consumed with the quest to create something perfect that will define their life's work and secure their legacy. They lose sight of right and wrong in pursuit of the finest materials and exciting opportunities.

{@b Attentive Overseer}. A guild representative takes personal interest in your group's tasks. They follow your exploits and know of your adventures before you return to report. Despite the unsettling depth of their knowledge, they seem genuinely eager to shepherd your work.

{@b Hidden Benefactor}. Whoever your contact is, they don't communicate directly. They send messages via couriers or letters. No one in the guild knows who the contact is, or if they do, they aren't telling you. Regardless, the contact's information is good, and they pay on time.

{@b Discerning Mentor}. No matter how well you perform, or how perfect your creations, nothing is ever good enough for this contact. They point out every flaw and missed opportunity. Are they bitter, lashing out at anyone around them, or do they recognize your potential and try to push you to greatness?

{@b Golem Guide}. Your guild contact is the soul of a long-dead artisan preserved in a construct body. This golem is wise and knowledgeable, but it has difficulty grasping the passage of time and the state of the world compared to its original era.

{@b Fallen Muse}. Your contact is a fallen celestial. Whether they regret their transgressions or hunger for vengeance, they provide divine inspiration and guidance to you and to the guild. Somehow your group and the guild inspire their hope for ascension.
table.name: Guild Contact

table.caption: Guild Representative Roles
rows: {@background Charlatan}, {@background Entertainer}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Noble}, {@background Sailor}
{@background Charlatan}, {@background Criminal}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Soldier}, {@background Urchin}
{@background Criminal}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Sailor}, {@background Soldier}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Sailor}
table.name: Guild Representative Roles

table.caption: Guild Quests
rows: {@b Deliver Goods}. You need to deliver an order to an important customer or partner of the guild. The delivery must arrive by a critical deadline—regardless of who or what tries to stop you.

{@b Acquire Materials}. Your guild requires materials that are rare and difficult to procure, either for a guild project or for a paying client. Your group must gather the missing components from a dangerous location or a recalcitrant owner while outpacing a rival to the prize.

{@b Eliminate a Rival}. A competitor has humiliated the guild one too many times, and it's time for that to stop. Your group is charged with assuring the rival never darkens the guild's reputation again. Can you trick them into permanent disgrace, or must you resort to more direct methods?

{@b The Masterpiece}. An exquisite work of art for an influential client, either created by your guild or acquired through agents, has gone missing. You must track down its whereabouts and secure it before time runs out and the guild suffers a penalty.

{@b The Collector}. Your guild is tasked to create or acquire something wondrous for a wealthy but secretive client's collection. Guild members who previously failed to fulfill this assignment ended up missing. The collector promises to return your comrades if you provide what the collector seeks, but if you fail, you'll become part of the collection.

{@b The Bill Comes Due}. Your guild master achieved their vaunted position by means of an otherworldly bargain. That price has come due, and they are desperate to avoid paying. You must defeat whatever's coming to collect the master's debt or find another acceptable payment.
table.name: Guild Quests

table.caption: Military Force Types
rows: {@b Standing Army}. A standing army serves as the highly disciplined and structured guardian of a province or an entire nation. Strict tiers of command ensure coordination between branches of the force.
{@b Mercenary Company}. Hard-bitten veterans of numerous conflicts, mercenaries serve an employer for coin rather than out of loyalty.

{@b Expeditionary Force}. This military force is far from home, fighting behind enemy lines or striking into wild, unsettled lands. The force must be fast, self-sufficient, and either diplomatic or decisive to assure their survival.

{@b Horde}. The horde is almost a force of nature, and what it lacks in discipline it makes up in ferocity. It doesn't have a rigid command structure, instead functioning like a pyramid of smaller armies. Horde commanders owe fealty to stronger leaders above them, all the way up to the warlord.

{@b Planar Conscripts}. This military force battles for cosmic stakes on far-flung planes of the multiverse or fights against extraplanar invasion on the Material Plane. Warriors include conscripts pressed into service in the Blood War, fodder in the thrall of ruthless yugoloth mercenaries, or members of a glorious celestial host defending against fiendish incursion.

{@b Sky Warriors}. This military force consists of winged creatures, employs magical flight, or sails airships as a sky navy. Traditional defenses are ineffective against attacks from the air, positioning the sky warriors as a fearsome nation or expensive and coveted mercenaries.
table.name: Military Force Types

table.caption: Commanding Officer
rows: {@b Tested Veteran}. Your commander is a battle-scarred officer who experienced horrors in combat. They rely on something to dull the pain of their memories or wounds, from a favorite writer's prose to a distracting vice.

{@b Taskmaster}. This angry officer yells every order, reprimands you for the smallest mistake, and fully expects you to fail at every mission you undertake. This might be tough love or simple brutishness.
{@b Protective Officer}. A kindly officer is hesitant to send you into danger and constantly reminds you to be careful.
{@b Bitter Soldier}. Your commander carries deep grudges against your force's enemies. They leap at any chance to do those foes harm, even if it puts your group in terrible risk.
{@b Hopeful Commander}. This optimistic officer knows that a new era of peace is just over the horizon. You just need to complete these last few missions, then it should all finally be over.
{@b Devout Leader}. Your commander is a person of deep faith. They believe that your success or failure lies entirely in divine hands and you are the instruments of that will.
table.name: Military Force Contact; Commanding Officer

table.caption: Military Force Envoy Roles
rows: {@background Criminal}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Sailor}, {@background Soldier}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Sage}, {@background Soldier}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Hermit}, {@background Sage}, {@background Soldier}
table.name: Military Force Envoy Roles

table.caption: Military Quests
rows: {@b Strike Force}. You undertake a quick, strategic, and devastating attack against an enemy force.
{@b Defensive Operations}. You must preserve the safety of an important location such as a civilian population center, a supply depot, or strategically critical bridge or seaport.

{@b Special Forces}. You are assigned to a covert operation behind enemy lines. This is similar to the work of a spy or an assassin but with a broader scope. You engage in equipment sabotage or execute targeted strikes against high-value targets.
{@b Reconnaissance}. You gather information on enemy troop numbers, placements, movement, or supply caches and routes.
{@b Seek and Destroy}. You are responsible for hunting down specific high-value and dangerous targets, which include deserters, suspected enemy special forces, or magical war machines run amok.
{@b Siege}. You are assigned to initiate a siege on an enemy stronghold or help break a siege in progress on an allied fortress.
table.name: Military Quests

table.caption: Religious Order Types
rows: {@b Undead Hunters}. This community of scholars and monster hunters laboriously researches the unquiet dead, tracking them to their lairs and permanently laying them to rest.
{@b Devout Scholars}. This federation prizes knowledge and texts pertaining to their god. They collect rare holy books and record the life stories of miracle-working prophets.
{@b Relic Collectors}. This order of archaeologist-monks seeks to fill their museum-like temple with storied holy relics.
{@b Charitable Missionaries}. Adhering to the belief that religion empowers civilization, this order travels far to help the downtrodden, seeking to draw new believers by their virtuous example.
{@b Militant Inquisitors}. This dogmatically rigid hierarchy seeks to stamp out all threats to their beliefs.
{@b Doomsaying Evangelists}. This order believes the world is about to end. They're convinced that if they persuade everyone else of this fact they might stave off the impending doom.
table.name: Religious Order Types

table.caption: Religious Order Contact
rows: {@b Shadow Tongue}. A mysterious speaker for your order advises your next steps but fears being discovered by a powerful rival faith.
{@b Inspired Creator}. A gifted artisan conveys the will of the divine through prophetic song or artwork.
{@b Mysterious Text}. The gradual translation of a secret holy text points you toward the next step of a divine destiny.
{@b Fierce Inquisitor}. A severe hierarch directs you to cleanse wickedness from a region, from the order, or from within yourself.
{@b Beloved Healer}. A famed healer guides you to where you'll be needed most, even if their reasons are unclear until you arrive.
{@b Divinity's Voice}. Otherworldly messages direct you to undertake divine quests.
table.name: Religious Order Contact

table.caption: Religious Order Member Roles
rows: {@background Acolyte}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Hermit}, {@background Sage}, {@background Urchin}
{@background Acolyte}, {@background Criminal}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Outlander}, {@background Soldier}
table.name: Religious Order Member Roles

table.caption: Religious Order Quests
rows: {@b Safe Escape}. A band of the faithful wandered into territory hostile to your order. You must find them and escort them to safety.
{@b Relic Recovery}. You seek a lost symbol of the order discovered in a dangerous place or in the hands of an enemy.
{@b Cult Hunt}. You hunt a cell of zealots dangerous to your order or mortals at large.
{@b Desperate Pilgrimage}. You protect members of the order as they participate in a pilgrimage that takes them through dangerous lands.
{@b Expunge Heresy}. You seek out the source of blasphemy that's taken root within the order.
{@b Prevent Prophecy}. A rival order stands on the cusp of fulfilling a prophecy with deadly ramifications. You strive to undermine their blasphemous agenda.
table.name: Religious Order Quests

table.caption: Sovereign Types
rows: {@b Village Elder}. The wizened leader of a community offers both civic and moral leadership.
{@b Young Noble}. An ambitious noble eagerly seeks to reform society to align with a personal vision.
{@b Shipwrecked Governor}. A desperate leader struggles to keep people alive in a wilderness they're not prepared to endure.
{@b Ruler Returned}. A tribe's revered leader has returned from the dead and seeks to resurrect their past glories.
{@b Hidden Power}. A mysterious figure manipulates the nation's puppet leader and guides the government's true agenda.
{@b True Regent}. The rightful heir to the throne struggles to reclaim power from a perfect impostor.
table.name: Sovereign Types

table.caption: Sovereign Contact
rows: {@b Intimate Confidant}. The sovereign's friend or lover seeks to aid their companion in any way possible.
{@b Spymaster}. An intelligence operative attends to the nation's dirty work so the sovereign keeps their hands clean.
{@b Administrator}. This severe bureaucrat disagrees with many of the sovereign's policies but takes loyal service seriously.
{@b Executive Assistant}. The responsibilities of an exacting butler or other servant at the royal household far exceed their title.
{@b Envoy}. A semi-retired, leisure-loving ambassador speaks in suggestion and innuendo.
{@b Spectral Assembly}. A ghostly council of the nation's previous regents manifests to avert disasters.
table.name: Sovereign Contact

table.caption: Sovereign Proxy Roles
rows: {@background Acolyte}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Noble}, {@background Sage}, {@background Soldier}
{@background Charlatan}, {@background Folk Hero}, {@background Guild Artisan}, {@background Noble}, {@background Sailor}
table.name: Sovereign Proxy Roles

table.caption: Sovereign Quests
rows: {@b International Espionage}. You attempt to steal intelligence, national symbols, or super weapons from an enemy power.
{@b Undermine Rival}. You seek to weaken or remove a rival to the regent's rule—perhaps a general, an archdruid, or a noble with a claim to the throne.
{@b Expel Corruption}. You help the sovereign reform their government, rooting out institutional vices.
{@b Subvert Blame}. The sovereign is caught in an embarrassing affair. Make it disappear.
{@b Test Heir}. You prepare the sovereign's heir for the challenge of taking the throne.
{@b Desperate Diplomacy}. You seek to make peace with a force or entity that could wipe out your nation.
table.name: Sovereign Quests

Tiny whimsical or fearsome beings from the spellcaster's inescapable, recurring dreams
